text: Darkness. Quiet. The CAMERA MOVES through the gloom of th small, dirty, wooden hut, past a broken table, over a wel worn saddle lying on the floor. Now, a pair of boots stan empty by the rotting remains of a rough-hewn bunk, up to holstered gun hung on the corner of the bed. The still sh of a man, a bedroll his only protection from the splinter planks. This is EMMETT, fast asleep. The door of the shack bursts inward as a Gunman crashes i For a moment he is silhouetted against the blinding morni light, his two six-guns blasting even before the door has bounced shut behind him, returning the hut to darkness. Emmett's holster, the gun gone. The gun is here in Emmett's hand, erupting now with three quick explosions. The intruder flies against the far wall the hut and lands on the floor dead. From outside, two bu pierce the plank wall behind Emmett, light streaming thro in .45 calibre shafts. Emmett is out of the bunk and on the floor. He fires once over the bunk. In the moment of quiet that follows, we he running FOOTSTEPS outside the hut. Emmett follows their  progress with the point of his gun, but holds his fire.  Suddenly a shotgun blasts a large hole in the roof of the shack, and the table disintegrates in a new column of lig Emmett glances upward, but quickly returns his attention the side walls, trying to follow that gunman. Now more fi comes from there and more footsteps. Another shotgun blas showers Emmett with debris, but he ignores it, concentrat on the walls. WHAT HE SEES. The Man Outside moves quickly past a crack the wall, momentarily revealing his spot by blocking the  light. Emmett fires once ahead of him, stopping his progr and forcing him back to the crack. Emmett fires his last  shot there, and the man outside goes down hard. The shotgun rips another jagged hole in the ceiling and b a crater in the dirt by Emmett's foot. The shape of a man flashes across the new hole. Emmett looks across the room the top bunk, where the barrel of his Winchester protrude few inches from the bare planks. Emmett throws his empty gun noisily into the far corner of the hut. Instantly the man on the roof blasts away in that direction. Emmett dives for the bunk. With the tips of his fingers, pulls hard on the muzzle. The Winchester flips full circl into the air as the bunk behind it is shredded from above With an odd kind of inevitability, as though seeking its  rightful place, the Winchester arcs into a shaft of light where it is met by Emmett's steady, waiting hands. Before has even settled, he has cocked and fired twice through a hole in the roof. Emmett stops and lowers the carbine. Th Man on the Roof falls spread-eagled through the weakened  ceiling. Debris and sunlight shower his lifeless form. Emmett listens, moves silently to the door, and opens it  carefully. WE FOLLOW him outside, out into the bright  sunlight, into the awesome promise of the American West.

Emmett moves warily around the isolated shack. There are more attackers. He looks off into the distance. Two rider horses, galloping away, are the only moving things in the empty landscape. A third saddled horse, a pinto, stands  nervously near Emmett's horse, which is tied to a stake. Emmett walks to the body of the Man Outside and looks dow at him. He doesn't know him. He moves to the pinto and ca it. He examines the distinctive brand on its flank, a cir with two wavy lines beneath it. Emmett is clearly mystifi He rests his arms on the saddle and stares after the  retreating horses. THE MAIN TITLE BEGINS.

Emmett travels, the saddled pinto in tow. He moves from h mountain terrain down-country, through meadow and canyon. makes night camp near a rushing stream. The land flattens he approaches the desert. The sun beats at him as he dism at the edge of a white-hot plain. He takes a short pull f his canteen and squints off across the flat, empty space. All he can see ahead is blinding sand and blue sky. THE MAIN TITLE ENDS.

Emmett is now surrounded by the white blankness, moving s under the broiling sun. He stops his walking horses and squints out into the dist seeing something. We see it too, but just barely: a dista horizontal smudge on the glaring sand. Emmett reaches the smudge. It is a man, barefoot and dres only in longjohns, his head propped on a rock, eyes close The man's skin is burned red and beginning to blister, hi lips parched. Yet there is a curious ease to his repose. he has lain down here to die, he has done it in peace. Th is PADEN. Emmett lifts Paden's head and puts the canteen to his lip Paden's eyes struggle to open in the glare. He takes a fe sips of the water. His lips crack with a slight smile at taste. He looks up at Emmett, takes another sip, and trie to speak. Emmett must lean down to hear his raspy whisper he tries again.
Pleased to meet you.
The terrain here is more hospitable. Paden, wrapped snugl in a blanket, lies with his head against the saddle from pinto. Emmett is preparing his bedroll across the fire.
Two of the horses ran off, but that  pinto you're riding hung around.
You got no idea what they were after?
Emmett shakes his head "no".
Offend anybody lately?
Not for five years.
Paden understands.
Jefferson City?
No, Leavenworth.
I've never been in there. They just  jumped you out of the blue?
I had to get up anyway.

(smiles) Me, I'm riding along, minding my own  business. Four cowboys come by and  we decide to ride together for a  while, friendly as can be. I always  figure you might as well approach  life like everybody's your friend or  nobody is... don't make much  difference. We get out in the middle  of that frying pan and suddenly  everybody's pointing their gun but  me. I guess they admired my horse.  She's a great one, a sweet little  bay.
Looks like that's not all they  admired.

Yup. The whole rig. I don't care  much about the rest, but I surely  will miss that bay. Least they didn't  kill me. That was right considerate,  I thought. They were laughing when  they left me. Thought it was real  funny. I walked for a little while  but there was no use, so I gave it  up. Figured it was just bad luck.
Emmett comes over and fills Paden's coffee cup.
Looks like those boys are headed  south, so they weren't the same ones  that jumped me. Which way you going?
Where's the pinto going?
I gotta stop by Turley and meet a  guy.
Where's Turley?
South of here, past Chimayo.
Maybe I'll go along as far as Chimayo.  Get me some clothes. Maybe a bath.
Yeah, maybe a bath.
Emmett settles down at his saddle and pulls a blanket ove himself. Paden glances at the rifle in its scabbard on th pinto's saddle by his head.
Is this loaded?
Emmett nods and closes his eyes. Paden smiles at the impl trust and settles down himself.
Emmett and Paden, who is still clad only in longjohns, ri toward the low, adobe settlement of Chimayo.
Emmett and Paden enter the town past a cluster of teepees Three Cavalry troopers ride past them.

The little settlement is the center of civilization for m around. The U. S. Cavalry maintains an outpost here, and  there are many soldiers on the street. Emmett and Paden p up to the general store. Paden dismounts and hands his re to Emmett. Passersby look with curiosity at the undressed Paden.
I'll get these horses tended.
Paden nods and looks doubtfully at the store. He scratche himself. Emmett produces some money and flips Paden a coi Paden nods.
I'm good for it.

Emmett rides up the street, leading the pinto. Paden star toward the store and nearly collides with a shocked woman who covers the eyes of the little girl with her and cross the street. Paden gives an apologetic tip to his non-exis hat as he watches them go. Before he can turn back to the store, his eye is caught by something up the street. He r big. WHAT HE SEES. His horse, a good-looking bay. And, dawdlin his way out of a saloon, a disreputable-looking Cowboy. Paden's hand slaps his side, where his gun should be. He  grimaces and looks around desperately, then hurries into store.

The lone CLERK is showing a woman customer a bolt of clot at the back of the store. Paden hurries in and makes a be line to the display case holding handguns and ammo. He sp something he likes and taps the glass impatiently. The Cl reacts with distaste to Paden's appearance.
Excuse me, there --
I'll be with you in a moment, sir.

Paden looks out the front window, up the street. The Cowb is untying the bay's reins. Paden, more agitated now, glances back at the Clerk, then moves around and opens the back of the display case. He  extracts a shiny, new Colt .45. The Clerk reacts with ala and moves toward Paden.
Just a minute there, fella. When I'm  done with this lady --
I'll take this one.
He drops his coin on the case top.
(looking at coin) That one's twenty dollars.
Paden is frustrated. He leans to peer out the window agai
How much to borrow it?
These guns are for sale.
(indicates his coin) What can I get for that?
The Clerk gives up on putting him off and comes around th display case, disgruntled.
The Cowboy mounts the bay.
Paden holds a broken-down memory of a gun as though it we a cow chip.
(resigned) What's it take?
The Clerk holds up a box of shells.
This is extra.
Paden snatches it from his grasp and heads out of the sto
I'll be back.

Paden hurries out into the middle of the street. Several  passersby stop to look at him. A teenage girl lets out a  delighted shriek. IN FRONT OF THE SALOON. The Cowboy has turned the bay int the middle of the street and now looks to see what all th fuss is about. When he makes out Paden standing alone, hi expression changes. Paden is having trouble extracting a shell from the ammo  box. He glances up the street at the Cowboy and sees that has been spotted. He shakes one shell loose and drops the box, trying to insert the bullet in the gun. The Cowboy pulls his six-gun, leans forward, and spurs th bay hard toward Paden. He raises his gun and fires at Pad There is general alarm in the street as the bystanders di for cover. Paden gets the shell loaded as the Cowboy bears down on h firing. The bullets kick up the dust in front and back of Paden, who now raises his pistol slowly. A bullet tears  through the floppy material at his crotch. The Cowboy is  almost upon him when Paden fires. The Cowboy is knocked o the horse and hits the street dead.

A big, tough Cavalry SERGEANT has been summoned by a TROO and now walks briskly toward -- A small crowd gathered around Paden, who is affectionatel stroking his reacquired horse. Two troopers flank him  suspiciously. The Sergeant glances at the body of the Cow then pushes through the crowd and confronts Paden.
(indicating Paden) This is the man, Sergeant. He claims  the animal was stolen.
How do I know this is your horse?
The bay nuzzles Paden.
Can't you see this horse loves me?
I had a gal do that to me, but that  didn't make her my wife.
I'll tell you what, on the underside  of this saddle I got my name  scratched. Take a look and you'll  see.
Oh, yeah, and what would your name  be?
Paden.
The Sergeant and Paden both look to see COBB come through the crowd; he is an imposing man in a duster. Paden's rea is deep and mixed, a whole chapter in his life coming bac at him.
(quietly) Hello, Cobb.
Hello, Paden. How ya doing?
You know this man, Cobb?
I surely do.
(to troopers) Let's see that saddle.
One of the troopers uncinches the saddle and flops it ups down in the dust. "Paden" is scratched on the underside.
(satisfied) All right, move along, folks. Get  these children out of here.
The crowd begins to break up. Paden and Cobb are left fac one another. Cobb takes in Paden's longjohns.
I see you're prospering without me.
It's been a while.
Where's the dog?
Paden's look pierces Cobb, but he bends to pick up his sa and when he straightens, there is a smile on his face.

Cobb and Paden come out of the general store and start do the sidewalk. Paden is a little unsteady in a pair of che boots. A small pile of clothing is in his arms. On his he is a bad-looking new hat. He catches his reflection in a  window and tries to give the hat a rakish tilt.
Appreciate the loan. I'm good for  it.
Let's talk about that. (a beat) I'm looking for some men.
I've given that up.
So have I. I've got a legitimate job  now. I can use a guy like you.
(doubtful) You've got a legitimate job.
Yes, sir. You wouldn't believe it.
You're right.
Cobb stops and faces Paden.
This is mighty sweet, Paden. I think  I finally found my place in the world.
Well I'm real happy for you, Cobb.  But I think I'll keep looking for  mine.
KYLE, a tough associate of Cobb's, hurries up to them.
(to Cobb) He's getting out.
Kyle goes back up the street.
(smiling) C'mon, this'll interest you.
Cobb moves off after Kyle. Paden watches a moment  thoughtfully, then follows.

Kyle is digging into a saddlebag on one of three saddled  horses at the gate of the stockade. Trooper guards flank entrance. Cobb comes up and stares at the gate. Paden rea the end of the sidewalk and leans against a post, watchin The heavy gate is opened and a jailkeep steps out into th sunlight; he looks back into the gloom. TYREE comes out,  wearing civilian clothes, shackled hand and foot. He's me The jailkeep unlocks Tyree's irons and steps back, a litt too quickly. Tyree nods at Cobb and a smile slits his fac Kyle comes up and hands Tyree his holster. Tyree buckles on and bends to tie it to his thigh.
Look who's here, Tyree. It's our old  riding buddy.
Tyree looks up and straightens slowly at the sight of Pad No love lost. Cobb, standing between them, grins and then laughs. He takes the reins of his horse from Kyle and swi up.
I invited Paden to join us, but he's  not having any.
Kyle and Tyree mount up. Tyree looks down at the longjohn Paden with a sneer.
(like a knife) Where's the dog?
The three head out of the village, passing Paden.
(to Paden) You owe me thirteen bucks.
Cobb spurs his horse and the three gallop away in the dus
(to himself) Thirteen... bad luck.

Emmett and Paden come out of a restaurant. Paden is now b and fully dressed for the first time and he looks quite  different, better. The old gun he purchased is stuck in h belt. Three horses -- Emmett's, the pinto, Paden's bay -- are tied to the post in the street. Paden is fussing with his new, cheap hat. Emmett takes a  close look at Paden's bay.
I see what you like, she's mighty  pretty.

And bridle-wise, too. She's the only  thing I lost I really cared about. (he messes with his  hat, disgruntled) 'Cept for maybe my hat. It's a great  one. Got a pretty silver band on it.  My head spent three years training  it. (frowns at his new  hat) I surely do miss that hat.
Emmett gives him an amused look; this sounds kind of fami Emmett unties his two horses.
I gotta be going.
Going to Turley, was it?
(nods) Gotta meet a guy and head out for  Silverado.
Paden takes the excess reins of the bay and begins idly  slapping them around the post, distracted. Emmett swings to his horse.
What's Turley like?
(he doesn't make  distinctions) It's a town...
They got a saloon there?
I expect.
Women?
I expect.
Paden takes a long time looking around the village's main street. It doesn't look promising. Emmett regards him wit growing bemusement. Finally --
Maybe you want to ride along with me  as far as Turley.
Paden lights up slightly at the suggestion. He looks up a Emmett. This is how Paden makes his decisions these days. seems to be digesting it slowly.
Maybe... I'll ride along... as far  as Turley.
Emmett nods and turns his horses into the street. Paden m up and follows him.
The two men, leading the pinto, make their way through de country to Turley.

Near the corrals at the end of the main street of the sma town of Turley, a small WAGON TRAIN is loosely formed up, waiting. The settlers from the wagon train mill about. Se regard Emmett and Paden with unusual interest as they rid by on their way into town. One of the Settlers is a lovely young woman. She glances the two men, then returns her attention to her wagon. Bot Emmett and Paden notice her. She is HANNAH.
A tall gallows is being constructed in the middle of an  intersection. Emmett and Paden look it over as they ride  past. Two workmen pause in their labors and look them ove

This is the busy part of town. Amidst the street traffic pedestrians sits a wagon with three Settler men, who watc Emmett and Paden's arrival with enormous interest. As the two travelers hitch their horses in front of the saloon, oldest man, HOBART, approaches them with some agitation.
(yelling) Baxter, Hawley, where the hell have  you been? You're late! And I'll tell  you, I don't like it. It's a bad  start, boys.
Emmett and Paden exchange looks.
I've got my people sitting down  there... (indicates end of  street) ...swatting flies and raring to go.
I'm afraid it is a bad start, friend,  'cause my name isn't Baxter, and he  ain't Hawley.
You're not Baxter?
My name is Emmett.
(to Paden) And you're not Baxter, either?
No, I'm not Hawley.
Well, god-dammit! God-dammit!
Hobart turns and looks across to the other Settler men. H yells.
They ain't Baxter and Hawley! Where  the hell are Baxter and Hawley!
All this commotion has attracted some attention and amuse from passersby.
Quit your yelling, old man. We're  right here.
Hobart looks around to find two tough-looking men on hors back behind him -- BAXTER and HAWLEY.
Who you calling an old man?
Baxter gets down from his horse and smiles, friendly for  him. Emmett and Paden watch with interest.
(offers his hand) Calm down, Mr. Hobart. I'm Nord  Baxter. That there is my partner,  Tom Hawley.
Hobart takes his hand grudgingly. He's glad they showed u
(gruff) You're late. It's a bad start, boys.
(grinning) Yes, sir. We'll just have to get you  people to Silverado that much quicker.
Emmett and Paden have continued to watch. Now Hawley look over at them suspiciously.
All right. Let's get going.
You remember my letter, don't you,  Mr. Hobart? Half now and half when  we get there.
(remembering, impatient) I remember, I remember. C'mere.

Hobart, Baxter, and Hawley move to the wagon, where the t other Settlers wait. The younger of the two, CONRAD, eyes the guides suspiciously. Hobart speaks to the third man, huge, bearded fellow called EB. Eb sits upon a strongbox the bed of the wagon, an awesome blunderbuss in his arms.
Open the box, Eb.
Eb stands, unlatches the strongbox, and opens it, reveali an impressive cache of coins and paper money. Hobart extr a pouch of coins and hands it to Baxter, who pockets it.
Don't you want to count it?
Not at all, friend. We trust you.  Now let's get this train on its way  to Silverado.
Emmett and Paden watch the other five men head in the  direction of the wagon train. Paden looks over at Emmett.

At the back of the big room is a registration desk for th hotel and stairs to the rooms. Emmett and Paden are eatin near a table of three Tough Men. Emmett is questioning a  WAITRESS, and his questions are making her nervous.
...He's about my size, energetic  young fella, wears two guns in a  fancy rig. He'd be a stranger here.
(moving away quickly) I don't know him, I told you. I ain't  seen nobody.
Paden, munching on a biscuit, has noticed something out i the street; he gets up and walks to the entrance.

WHAT PADEN SEES. The wagon train is moving by. Paden's  attention is drawn to the seat of one of the wagons. Hann the lovely settler woman, is there; sitting beside her in husbandly manner is Conrad. Paden is interested enough in the pretty girl that he barely registers a new arrival at the saloon's hitching post. The newcomer takes his saddle bags and a Henry .44 rifle from his horse and comes up in the saloon.

The newcomer is a lithe, strong, black man -- MAL. He has other weapon besides the rifle. Mal looks around the room and walks wearily to the registration desk, although ther is no one behind it. He RINGS a bell for service. At the sound of the bell several of the patrons look up a spot Mal for the first time. The three Tough Men are inst displeased at the sight of the black man. Paden, returnin to his meal, notes their attitude and glances over at Mal Mal leaves his saddlebags at the registration desk, but t the rifle as he walks across to the bar. The nervous Wait is working there. The sight of Mal only adds to her agita
(cold) What do you want?
(friendly, tired) I haven't had a drink of whiskey or  slept in a bed for ten days. Give me  a bottle.

The Waitress hesitates, uncertain. She places a shot glas and a bottle on the bar beyond an elaborate, brass, nude  statuette whose upraised arms hold dishes full of hard-bo eggs. Mal has leaned his rifle against the bar and must n move a few steps to stand before the whiskey. The three Tough Men exchange looks as Mal uncorks the bot and slowly, lovingly fills his shot glass. He puts the bo down and regards the glass for a long moment of pleasant  anticipation. Mal's hand has started for the glass when t saloon's PROPRIETOR appears from a back room.
(sharply) Hey! What are you doing, buck?
Mal draws his hand back and straightens slightly. A diffe kind of weariness comes into his face.
Having a drink.
No, you're not. Get out of here.

The Proprietor shoots the Waitress a withering look; she  shrugs helplessly and hurries away. At the tables two of three Tough Men quietly rise and separate, moving toward two ends of the bar. Emmett and Paden watch.
(flat) I haven't had a drink of whiskey or  slept in a bed for ten days.
You ain't getting them here.
(gravely) I'm real sorry to hear that.
At this, the First Man steps forward quickly, snatches Ma rifle, and slides it down the bar. Mal looks across the  distance at his only weapon.
(quietly, to Emmett) Doesn't look quite fair.
(watching carefully) Which way do you mean?

The Second Man lurches up to the bar and pins Mal's arms  behind him. The First Man moves quickly, cocking back his arm for a punch square in Mal's face. As the blow is  unleashed, Mal bends forward with terrific speed and forc pulling the Second Man onto his back. The Second Man's fa is suddenly where Mal's was an instant ago, and the First Man's punch lands hard on it. Mal slams the Second Man's  back against the edge of the bar; he falls to the floor. blocks a blow from the First Man and steps in with a flur of body blows. Back at the Tough Men's table, the Third Man pushes back chair as if to rise. Emmett has just picked up a chicken  leg; now he waves it ever so slightly at the Third Man: " out of it". The Man looks at Emmett and Paden, then settl back into his seat. Mal sends the First Man crashing down through a table wit final blow. He turns in time to see the Second Man, back his feet, grab Mal's whiskey bottle and break it against bar. Mal looks for a frustrated moment at the splashing  whiskey -- what a waste. The Second Man lunges with the s glass. Mal lifts the heavy statuette easily with one hand and uses its upraised arms to catch the Man's wrist and t the bottle painfully from his grasp. Mal's other hand hit the Man once in the throat, and he is down. The Proprietor rises from behind the bar, a sawed-off sho in his hand. Mal spins, swinging the statuette brutally  against the Proprietor's arm. The shotgun clatters to the floor as the Proprietor recoils in pain, crashing into a  shelf of glasses. The fight is over. Suddenly, standing in the doorway holding a leveled gun i an enormously tall figure -- SHERIFF LANGSTON. Dressed ra elegantly in suit and bowler, he dwarfs the man at his si DEPUTY KERN. He surveys the scene as the three injured me stir back to life. When he speaks, it is, surprisingly, w a British accent --
What's all this then?
This nigger's breaking up my place,  Sheriff Langston.
I don't like that word much, Carter.
We don't serve them here and you  know it. I asked him to leave and he  went crazy on us. He owes me money  for this damage.
Is that a fact?
'Fraid not, Sheriff. These other  fellas started the ruckus.
Langston's attention focuses on Emmett and Paden.
There are three strangers in this  room, traveller, and these gents you  are accusing aren't them. (to Mal, indicating  Emmett and Paden) Are these your friends?
(shakes his head "no") I wanted a drink and a bed. I guess  I came to the wrong place.

(taking in the mess) Came to the wrong town. I don't  tolerate this kind of thing. It's  hard on the peace, and it's hard on  the furniture. Now, knowing a bit  about Carter here, I'm going to let  you go without paying for the damages.  But go you will, and I mean now.
Is there a place in town that takes...  my kind?
You misunderstand. I want you out of  town. In fact, I want you all the  way out of my jurisdiction.
(seething) That ain't right.
I decide what's right in this  jurisdiction. Now move.

Mal glares at Langston and, finally, moves. He takes his  rifle from the bar, then walks over, picks up his saddleb and slings them over his shoulder. He is almost to the do when he stops, turns, and walks slowly back to the bar. T shot glass full of whiskey has miraculously survived the  fracas. Mal brings it to his lips and swallows with  satisfaction. He turns and goes out the front door. Langs motions to Deputy Kern to follow and witness Mal's depart Langston turns and looks at Emmett and Paden as he slowly uncocks his revolver and holsters it.
Who's going to pay for all this,  Sheriff?
Don't press your luck, Carter.
Langston moves to Emmett and Paden's table and pulls up a chair. He lifts the last biscuit from a basket. He takes fastidious bite.
Now let's talk about you chaps.
We'd rather stay.
We'll see about that. I'm Sheriff  John Langston. As you may have  guessed, I am not from these parts.
You're kidding.

(ignoring that) But the good citizens of Turley have  taken me in their embrace, and for  one simple reason. I maintain the  peace. So when strangers come to  town, I always ask them their  business. Have you come for the  hanging?
("no") I'm just meeting a guy here and moving  on. So far I haven't been able to  find him.
In my town, when you're looking for  someone, you ask me.
All right. I'm looking for a young  fella, full of juice. About my size,  wears a fancy two-gun rig.
Langston takes a long time reacting to this information. he slides his chair back a foot, giving his gun hand a li more room.
I know where that gentleman is.

A lean, young man is bouncing around his cell, playing ha sack, keeping a small, leather, bean bag from falling to floor by kicking it with his bare feet. This is JAKE. Langston opens the door to the cellblock and speaks over shoulder to Emmett and Paden, who have removed their guns
Now I want everyone to behave himself.

At the sight of Emmett, Jake's face lights up. And then h does an extraordinary thing: with one long stride he is a the cell and into the air; he hits the bars halfway up an clings like a monkey. Paden reacts as if he is one.
Emmett! Am I glad to see you!
(touching him) Howdy, Jake. What's going on here?
You got me. This is a crazy town,  Emmett. I think we ought to get out  of here.
Jake lowers himself and darts about as he talks.
All I did was kiss a girl.
(skeptical) That's why they got you in jail?
Yeah, I kissed a girl and this guy  didn't like it and we had some words,  so I decided to get out of there.
Jake looks at Emmett as though that should make it perfec clear. Emmett waits.
So I did, I got out of there, I don't  want no trouble. You know me. (indeed, Emmett does) So I walked out on the street and  the fella tried to shoot me in the  back.
...And you had to kill him?
No, no, no! I winged him, and he  dropped his gun.
You're in here for winging a guy?
Paden watches, fascinated.
Well, no, not exactly. See then his  friend opened up on me.
What friend is that?
The one with the shotgun.
The dead one.
There is a long moment of silence in the cellblock.
Jake, I'm going to ask you once --  was it self-defense?
(after a moment,  quieter now) Honest to God, Emmett, he would've  killed me.
The jury saw it differently.
(putting it all  together) So this is the guy you're going to  hang?
Tomorrow morning. Ten o'clock.
(nods) I was afraid of that.
Emmett steps back and leans against the opposite wall, lo down at his boots.
Emmett, can't you help me?
Emmett looks up at the young man. He looks sad.
Jake, you know the law. You know  what they did to me.
Jake remembers. It makes him gloomy.
Blind Pete always said you'd hang.
Jake's eyes flick over Emmett, but his expression doesn't change.
I guess tomorrow at dawn he'll be  proved right.
Ten A.M.
Right... I thought they always did  it at dawn. (to Jake) So long, kid. I'm sorry.
Emmett walks out. Jake watches as the other two follow.
Emmett and Paden walk along the sparsely populated sidewa They are quiet for a few moments. Finally --
Shame about the kid. Seems a lively  sort.
(morosely) He is that.
I hate to see any man swing. Bad  luck.
Bad luck for me. Now I gotta bust  him out of there.
Paden stops. Emmett has moved a couple more steps before notices and turns back to Paden.
You'll have to deal me out on that.  I've had some experience with that  sort of thing, and I don't want any  more.
I understand.
It's not going to be easy.

It never is. But he's my brother. (Paden reacts) We're going to California together.  But first we're going to stop in  Silverado and see our sister. And I  can't show up there with a story  like this.
Paden nods. He is sympathetic.
Then I guess this is where we part  ways. Sorry.
No hard feelings.
C'mon, I'll buy you a drink.
You haven't got any money.
All right, you buy me a drink.
They cross the street toward the crowded, noisy saloon.
You know, a good smelly saloon is my  favorite place in the world.

This is the busiest place in town, really packed. Emmett  heads for a spot at the bar, but Paden, who is taking in scene with relish, stops in his tracks, staring across th room. WHAT HE SEES. Through the moving jumble of bodies and the heavy smoke, Paden's hat with its silver band, floating a an unseen head at a poker table. Paden adjusts the old gun stuck in his belt and goes in t direction. At the table a heavy game is in progress. An UGLY COWBOY wearing Paden's hat. Paden plants himself across the tabl from the man. In seconds, Paden's posture brings things t halt. Quiet ripples out across the room. The Ugly Cowboy  looks up and recognizes Paden.
You're wearing my hat. What else you  got that's mine?
I don't know what you're talking  about, mister.
He shifts a little in his chair. His right hand slides of the table. Bystanders back away. Emmett watches from the  bar.
I hope your hand isn't tickling my  bone-handled Colt. If you stand up  real slow and let me see, you might  live through this night.

The Ugly Cowboy hesitates, his eyes darting. He pushes hi chair back slowly and begins to rise as if in compliance. But now a bone-handled Colt is in his hand, clearing his  holster. Paden is quicker. He snatches his gun from his b and fires. Paden's eyes, squinting through a cloud of gunsmoke, as w hear the Ugly Cowboy's body CRASH to the floor in his cha Paden's glance now darts down at an angle. WHAT HE SEES. His hat lands on the saloon floor, spins on on its brim, and settles into stillness like a tossed coi Silence in the saloon. Then, in a far corner, the BANGING chairs and a door SLAMMING. Paden's gun points that way, there is no one there. Only an overturned chair, and an e pair of boots -- Paden's. Paden picks up his hat and walks toward his boots. Emmett moves to the dead man, unbuckles the gunbelt, and pulls i free of the body. He picks up the bone-handled Colt and p it in the holster, then stops abruptly. We hear the stead advance of FOOTSTEPS across the saloon floor. Emmett's ey follow the off-screen presence. Paden, seated, is pulling on his newly-regained boots wit delighted air when a shadow surges up and engulfs him. He looks up. Sheriff Langston towers over him.
Paden is brusquely deposited in the cell next to a surpri Jake by Sheriff Langston and DEPUTY BLOCK.
You're making a big mistake.
Langston is not interested. He and Block go out.
That's what I told 'em.
Deputy Block eyes Emmett, who loiters by the door as Lang settles himself.
Maybe I ought to throw you in jail  too. Then you could be with all your  friends.
I haven't done anything.
I want you out of town before the  hanging.
I'll be long gone.
Paden forlornly regards a snoring drunk in another cell a Jake talks to him.
You mean you ain't coming with Emmett  and me?
I can't say I'm convinced you're  going anywhere.
Sure we are. We're leaving at dawn.
I've got no reason to run. It was a  fair fight and there were plenty of  witnesses.
(bubbly) Yeah, that's what happened with me  too.
The other guy drew first.
(same for him) Right!
Paden looks a little discouraged, but is still unconvince
Emmett sits up on the new gallows in the deserted  intersection, his legs dangling through the dropped trap  door. Now he begins idly collecting wood shavings into a  little pile.
Paden steps close to the bars that separate the cells and looks up at Jake, who is dangling at arm's length from on of the overhead bars in his cell.
(whispering) Your brother seems pretty good, but  it isn't going to be easy getting in  here.
Jake drops down to the floor.
He ain't coming in, we're going out. (motions) Gimme your belt.
Paden, trying to follow this, unbuckles his belt.
Didn't he tell you about Blind Pete?
(handing him the belt) We didn't get that far.
Blind Pete taught me a great trick.
Jake grasps Paden's belt by the buckle and snaps it at Pa with a CRACK, like a lion tamer.
Deputy Block cheats at solitaire while Langston dozes at desk. Now we hear FOOTSTEPS and BANGING outside.
Sheriff! Sheriff! Open up!
Block unlocks the door as Langston comes groggily to life STABLE BOY bounces at the door, pointing off.
Sheriff Langston, come quick!
He disappears. Langston goes out, calling back to Block -
Lock this door and don't let anybody  in.
Langston hurries up the street after the Stable Boy.
Deputy Block bolts the front door.
(shouting) Hey! What are you doing, you crazy  kid? Don't do it!
Block draws his six-gun and edges suspiciously toward the door to the cellblock.
Oh, Jesus! Somebody stop him!
Block turns the doorknob and pushes the door open with hi foot, gun ready. He moves into the cellblock.

Block moves cautiously to where he can see the cells. A  strange look crosses his face. Jake is hanging by the neck from the overhead bars, two b forming the noose, his head at a disgusting angle from hi body. One foot gives a final twitch and he is still.
Cut him down! For God's sake, cut  him down!
Block is confused, uncertain. He doesn't want to go in th
Hurry up! You might be able to save  him!
What for? So we can hang him?
Paden, sincerely desperate now, looks up at Jake, whose f is turning blue.
I think I'm going to be sick... when  I see what Langston does to you when  he gets here.
Block lets it sink in, then takes some keys from his belt
(to Paden) You get way back there.

Paden moves back quickly, motioning for Block to hurry. B holsters his six-gun, opens Jake's cell door, and goes in He gets up on the cot, pulling a knife from a sheath. He  strains up against Jake's body, stretching to cut the bel Suddenly Jake can stand it no longer: he sputters to life his long-held breath blasting in Block's face. Block,  startled, stumbles backwards off the cot, raising the kni threateningly. Jake grabs the overhead bars, swings up, a kicks Block in the chest. The deputy careens across the c and hits the bars. He throws the knife outside the cell a draws his gun, ready to shoot Jake. As Block's finger pulls the trigger, Paden's thumb intrud between the hammer and the firing pin. Paden has reached  through the bars behind Block to grasp the gun with his r hand. Now with his left he grabs a handful of Block's hai and slams the deputy's head hard back against the bars. A Block slides unconscious to the floor, Paden keeps the gu wincingly uncocking it.
Got to be real quiet here.
Jake has unhooked himself and is freeing his makeshift no He rubs his reddened neck.
(a hoarse whisper) Right.

Langston huffs to a stop next to the Stable Boy, his  countenance a picture of outraged befuddlement. He, the S Boy, and just one other surprised citizen are the only  witnesses: the gallows is aflame, burning like a pyre. Langston considers this phenomenon, a suspicion slowly gr in his mind.

Paden and Jake come out warily. The street is deserted. P straps his holster on; he's glad to have it back at last. Not as glad, however, as Jake, who seems to have a nearly religious relationship with his rig, an elaborately toole double gunbelt with two pearl-handled Colts.
That's the longest I ever did it.  'Bout bust a gut.
(finger to lips:  "quiet") What now?
We wait.

The two men move carefully off the porch and into the str A wood stair goes up the outside of the jail to a door. N high behind Jake, Deputy Kern comes out, nightshirt flapp cocking the carbine in his hands. He has thumped down fiv steps before he focuses on Jake and Paden. He starts to r the carbine. Both men see the deputy, but Jake's reaction is so fast t Paden need only watch. Jake spins and, before he has stop both his Colts are erupting in his hands. The carbine fli out of Kern's grasp and clatters down the steps. Jake  continues to fire -- the stair at Kern's foot splinters a he steps backwards and up. Jake continues to splinter the steps at Kern's feet, until he has made the deputy exactl retrace his steps and retreat back through the door. The  firing stops. Paden gives Jake an odd look. Paden may have seen someone this fast and good before, but he can't remember it. He p his finger to his lips -- "shhh".
Where's your brother?
(reloading fast) He'll be here.

A bullet WHIZZES between the two men as we hear shots fro the far end of the street. Langston is coming toward them firing. They move back to the cover of the jail porch. ALLEY ACROSS THE STREET. Emmett roars into view, riding h horse and leading two others: Paden's bay and the pinto. A window above the jail breaks open and Kern starts firin at Emmett. DOWN THE STREET. Langston, behind a wagon, uses a British two-handed grip to fire off a few rounds. Emmett brings the horses over, and Paden swings quickly u Jake focuses his attention, unleashing a fusillade as Emm leads the pinto along the front of the jail.
Jake, come on!

DOWN THE STREET. Langston lifts his head from behind the bullet-pocked wagon. He's impressed. Jake runs along the porch, hits the top of the hitching p on the fly, and takes off, landing lightly in the saddle the pinto. The three men gallop out of town in a cloud of dust.

The three men ride hell-for-leather away from town. At th first bend they leave the road and head off cross-country their horses straining up craggy hillsides and sliding do dusty slopes. There is some good riding going on here.

INTERCUTTING the three men and the Posse Langston has rai as the Posse closes ground over choppy terrain. Now the t fugitives come through some trees along the bank of a str and splash across to the other side.

The three men come thundering along a dusty trail to the  place where it splits. The high road disappears up the si of a ridge; the low road is really the bed of an arroyo. three men exchange looks. Paden plunges into the arroyo.  Emmett shrugs to Jake, and the brothers follow Paden. INTERCUTTING. The Posse splashes across the stream. The t fugitives twist their way through the crooked arroyo. AT THE SPLIT IN THE TRAIL. Langston pulls his group to a  halt. He looks at the tracks leading into the arroyo, and smile splits his face. He leads the Posse up the high roa fast.
IN THE ARROYO. Paden and Emmett pull up, looking back at  Jake, who has stopped at the last bend in the gully, watc their rear. Now he rides up to the others.
I think we lost 'em.
There's nobody coming?
Jake shakes his head "no". Paden and Emmett exchange long looks. Paden looks to the ground above them, even more  worried.
Oh-oh.
They spur their horses out of there.

The three riders break out of the arroyo and exchange loo of glee on seeing the clear flatlands ahead. SHOTS ring o They look over their shoulders to see Langston's Posse,  practically on top of them, pouring over the lip of a ris and firing at will. The three men whip their horses and head flat out across open space toward a cluster of boulders three hundred yar away. They are vulnerable and exposed as shots PING aroun them. They are not going to make it. WITH THE POSSE. Deputy Block jumps from his horse onto th top of a boulder and lies prone, bracing his Winchester f an accurate shot.
(to himself) Let's see you fake this one, kid.

He is about to fire when suddenly the rocky surface in fr of his face explodes. He is so startled, he falls off the boulder. Another Posse member is coming between two tall rocks whe bullet hits near his head and ricochets into the rock on other side. His horse rears up, and the horse coming up b him collides with it. Langston and Deputy Kern have just started across the fla but pull up next to a cactus at this new firing. An arm o the cactus is immediately severed by a .44 slug.
Is that them shooting?
(pointing) No. It's coming from those rocks.
WHAT HE SEES. Paden, Emmett, and Jake are now halfway to cover of the distant rocks. Another shot CRACKS, and a pu of smoke appears from ahead of them in the boulders.
Let's go. He ain't hitting anything.
You idiot, he's hit everything he's  aimed at.
...But they won't be out of our  jurisdiction till they pass Flat  Top!
As Paden, Emmett, and Jake disappear among the boulders,  Langston rises high in his stirrups to catch a final glim His bowler is blown off his head. He lowers himself back his saddle.
Today my jurisdiction ends here.
He turns his horse back. The others do likewise.
(over his shoulder,  to Kern) Pick up my hat.

Emmett and Paden rein in their frothing horses in the nat bowl of rocks near a tied horse and the remains of a camp Jake has stopped short of them and taken his horse back t peer out toward the Posse. Grinning, he comes back to the others. The three riders bring their horses around and fo on a spot above them. On the top of the highest boulder, Mal leaves a comfortab prone shooting position and eases himself down to a lower rock. A bandolier of .44 bullets dangles from one hand. H rests his Henry rifle at an angle across one shoulder.
(to the others) This a friend of yours?
He is now.
Who is he?
Oh, a guy who got run out of town...
...just like us.

An awesome rock spire soars into the perfect blue sky abo the orange desert. The sight is spectacular. The slow sur of MUSIC exhilarating. It is the perfect setting in which see the four horsemen who now appear on a ridge. Here the come -- Riding together, side by side, for the first time -- Emme Paden, Jake, and Mal.

The travellers crest a hill above a wide desert plain and pull up at the surprising sight below -- there in the  distance, stopped dead in a disorderly line, is the wagon train we saw leave Turley. The horsemen exchange puzzled  looks.

The Settlers are clustered near a wagon as the four horse ride down on them. There is a tense silence as they dismo and approach the group. Hobart, the leader, steps forward meet them. After a long perusal --
(calling) It's okay, Zeke.
From the cover of a nearby wagon, Zeke appears, lowering shotgun that had been trained on the newcomers.
Hobart, what are you people doing  here?
This is where Baxter and Hawley brung  us.
Well, they're wrong. This territory  is full of bad characters.
And they were two of them. Look --
He gestures and the Settlers part to reveal the wagon whi held the money box in Turley. The money box is gone, but still form of its giant guardian, Eb, lies in the bed of wagon, dead.
Baxter and Hawley killed poor Eb  here and stole our money box. (gestures) They went north and we're going after  them.
The newcomers now see that a few of the Settler men and b are preparing to ride in pursuit. Mal and Paden exchange  looks, not terribly impressed.
Forget the money. You've got to get  these people out of here. This is no  place to be sitting with women and  kids.
Your next water ain't for three days.
We got no life in Silverado without  that money. Everybody put in, that's  our whole stake.

Paden looks around. His gaze falls on Hannah, somber now, but still lovely. Conrad, her husband, stands beside her. Mal has been watching a little girl cling to the leg of o of the Settler men who is going out on the chase. Now the black man quietly mounts his horse, and speaks to an olde solid-looking man, MR. PARKER, standing by his wife.
How long have they been gone?
About an hour.
Emmett and Paden watch Mal with interest. Jake is excited this development. He jumps up on his horse.
I'll go with you, Mal!
Paden isn't so quick to commit, but then he notices Hanna gazing up at Mal and Jake with radiant admiration. He dig that and moves toward his horse.
Deal me in.
He steals a look at Hannah as he mounts up. Emmett has wa all this with growing resignation. Now he speaks crisply, all business.
Jake, you know the way out of here.  I want you to get this train moving  toward Silverado, and fast. I'll go  with these guys.
Jake is disappointed, but nods agreement. Emmett turns to Hobart and the Settler posse.
You men stay with your wagons and  your families. Get rolling and keep  your eyes peeled.
Emmett moves toward his horse, as Conrad, rifle in hand,  steps forward belligerently.
Wait a minute! If you do get the  money, how do we know you'll come  back?
(flashes him a look) If we don't, you can keep my brother.
(to Emmett) I'm trusting you, mister.
(to Hobart) You trusted Baxter. I'm not letting  these men out of my sight.
As Conrad moves toward his horse, Paden looks at Hannah, standing all alone. Paden thinks he acted too quickly.
(indicating Hannah) If I'd brought a pretty lady like  that into a place like this, I'd  stay close.
Paden reacts to Emmett's interest in Hannah.
That's none of your business, mister.  Let's get going.
(quietly, to Emmett) I think you got a point, Emmett.  Maybe I better stay here with her.

Emmett smiles and snaps his reins, moving out with Mal.  Reluctantly, Paden follows, twisting around for a last gl of Hannah. WHAT HE SEES. Hannah moves toward Conrad's horse, as if t touch her husband. But Conrad, his face set in suspicion, barely nods farewell as he sweeps by her. She looks after him desolately. Mal, Paden, Emmett, and Conrad ride off to the north, as  Jake begins yelling orders to the Settlers to get things  moving. What he lacks in expertise, he makes up for in  enthusiasm.

The four men track the killers across the rugged terrain. Sometimes, Emmett gets down from his horse to examine the tracks. On a flat, rocky expanse, the chase party is temporarily  stalled. Emmett and Paden confer, balked. Mal, peering ah spots something and points it out to the two expert track a steaming horse patty. They head off in that direction.

The four men crawl to the lip of the canyon and get a cle view of the activity below; the box canyon has been turne into a hideout for the Dawson Gang, a band of border raid There are about twenty-five outlaws moving about among th tents, caves, and wagons of the encampment. Their horses penned in a natural alcove in the rock off the main floor the canyon. The strongbox from the wagon train sits on the tailgate o wagon. Next to it is a large keg of whiskey from which th outlaws are drawing generous portions. Baxter and Hawley  have brought the loot proudly back to their cohorts, and celebration is centered around this wagon. On the rim the pursuers exchange looks in reaction to thi new situation.
(to Emmett) You know, hanging around with you is  no picnic.
Anybody got any ideas?

One of the outlaws spills some whiskey onto the money in strongbox. DAWSON, the leader of the gang, angrily slams strongbox closed and kicks the offending outlaw. Suddenly there are cries of warning from the Sentinel at the entra to the box canyon. HOOFBEATS echo into the canyon from th direction. The outlaws react en masse with a frightening  display of armed readiness. WHERE THE TRAIL ENTERS THE CANYON. From the shadows emerg two galloping horses: on the first is Emmett, who holds t reins of the second, across whose saddle is draped the  seemingly lifeless body of Paden. The Sentinel watches th pass under the point of his carbine. AT THE WAGON. Emmett dismounts quickly and ties both hors to a wheel. Dawson decides not to shoot this guy yet. He  watches as Emmett runs back across the canyon to the cove of some crates and crouches down behind them, looking up the rim above the entrance. The outlaws, guns pointed, st around him.
(to Dawson) Should I kill him, Mr. Dawson?
(approaching Emmett) In a minute!
Emmett, still cowering, looks over his shoulder at Dawson He speaks now, and throughout, very fast.
I wouldn't do that. You're going to  need every gun when that posse gets  here.
Posse? What the hell you talking  about?

My partner and me robbed the bank in  Turley and headed out with a posse  on our tails. My partner there caught  one a ways back, and I think he kicked  off while I was looking for this  damn canyon. You're Dawson, ain't  you? I'm Tex LaRue. (offers his hand for  only a second) Used to ride with Ry Morris. You  know him. Well, Andy Sims told me  there was a hideout here, so I headed  for it. Hope you don't mind.
Paden, lying over the saddle, his face shielded by his ha winces at this story.
You brought a posse to my best hideout  and you want to know if I mind.  Mister, I don't know any of those  names and you're about to die.
Wait a minute! If you don't believe  me, ask them... (indicates Baxter and  Hawley) ...they saw me and my pal in Turley  before we did the job.
Baxter and Hawley peer at Emmett and nod to each other.
I saw 'em there, all right, but I  don't know about any bank job.
If you took the bank in Turley,  where's the money?
Emmett crouches lower, looking nervously at the rocks.
I'd get down if I were you. They may  be up there now.
(just as he suspected) No money, eh?
The money's in my saddlebags over  there, but I ain't stepping out to  get it.

The outlaws, all of whom are standing in the open, think  he's crazy. Dawson motions Hawley toward Emmett's horse.  Hawley is almost there when gunfire erupts from the rocks above and Hawley goes down dead. Now all the outlaws hit dirt, some firing wildly. Paden unobtrusively frees his r Dawson comes down beside Emmett.
Conrad and Mal fire into the canyon, then move to new  positions.
ABOVE THE ENTRANCE to the box canyon the Sentinel disappe into the rocks, moving upward. AT THE CRATES. Down the line from Emmett, an outlaw gets  hit. The outlaws can't see anything to shoot at.
(agitated) If we charge them, they won't have a  chance. But we gotta get to the  horses.
What do you mean, the horses?
Emmett jumps up. He yells to the other outlaws.
Cover me!
He runs in a mad zig-zag toward the gate of the horses' p
Mal, firing rapidly, follows Emmett's route with precisio
Mal's shots kick up dust inches from Emmett's flying feet Once Emmett throws a glance upwards; Mal's cutting it pre close. Baxter slides in next to Dawson, who is thinking h
(indicating Emmett) Brave man.
I think there's only a couple of  guys up there and this asshole's one  of them.

AT THE WAGON. An outlaw is cowering beneath the wagon, bu doesn't notice as Paden reaches out and secures the latch the money box. AT THE HORSE PEN. Emmett throws open the make-shift gate runs in among the horses, yelling and waving his arms. Th horses begin to run out of the pen. AT THE CRATES. Dawson jumps up and orders his men forward line of outlaws rushes toward the pen, all the while firi up at the rim. Paden appears at a gallop from behind, pul Emmett's horse beside him. A rope stretches from his  saddlehorn to the strongbox bouncing along in the dirt. Paden comes through the line of outlaws firing and heads the pen. A few of the outlaws make the mistake of closing the gap and aiming at Paden's back. The bouncing strongbo knocks them head over heels. Emmett leaps from a rock onto his passing horse, firing b him. He and Paden go down the trail in the midst of the  outlaws' horses. The strongbox careens after them.

Mal and Conrad, mounted; are waiting as Emmett and Paden  ride out of the mouth of the canyon. Beyond them, the out horses scatter toward the horizon. Paden jumps off his ho and picks up the strongbox. IN THE ROCKS ABOVE THEM the Sentinel from the outlaw camp positions himself to fire at the men below.
(to Mal) That was some idea of yours. Next  time you go in.
Paden is tying the strongbox to his saddlehorn when there the loud CLICK of Conrad's rifle being cocked. He nervous points it at the others.
I knew it. Put that box on my horse.
Mister, you got a lot to learn about  people.
A SHOT rings out. Conrad takes it in the chest and flies his horse. Now an amazing sight -- Emmett, Paden, and Mal all turn and fire at once. The Sentinel is really dead.
Below in the distance the wagon train moves across the de dwarfed by giant rock walls. Now, coming right PAST CAMER at a gallop ride Emmett, Paden, Mal, and Conrad's horse w his body slung over it.
Hannah sits alone on the high seat of her wagon. She is  unaware that behind her the four horses approach. And tha her husband is dead.
Mal, Emmett, and Jake lounge about a campfire within the  quiet circle of wagons. Emmett is whittling a whistle pip out of a stick.

After the war my family worked a  little piece of land near Savannah  for a while. But the way it was down  there then... well, they made it  hard every way they could. Finally  my daddy figured the promised land  was out this direction. By that time  I was so sick of farming, I didn't  want to touch another hoe ever. I  wouldn't come with 'em. My daddy  took it pretty hard. Him, my ma, and  my little sister headed out without  me. They've got a little place south  of Silverado. I guess they've done  okay. Good enough anyway so that  when my ma wrote me last time, she  said they needed my help to work the  place. That was almost nine months  ago she wrote. Letter took a while  to find me, but when it did, it was  just the right time.
Where were you?
Chicago. Working in the slaughter- houses.
Chicago! You been to Chicago? Was it  wonderful?
(remembering) No.
Paden walks into the light of the fire and pours himself cup of coffee.
Where you been?
(caught, vamps) Oh, I was just checking the, ah... (gestures vaguely  over his shoulder) ...you know, lookin' in.
He concentrates on his coffee and moves away from the lig Mal, Emmett, and Jake exchange amused, knowing looks.
Jeez, Paden, her old man ain't even  cold yet!
Mal and Emmett laugh.
SERIES OF SHOTS as the wagon train rolls westward. Paden is driving Hannah's wagon; she sits beside him on t seat.
He acted bravely out there, Hannah.  Just bad luck his getting hit. Could  have been any one of us.
I don't believe in luck. I know what  Conrad was like. Don't tell me what  you think I want to hear.
Never will again.
We got married just before this trip,  so we could come out here and try  the land. It's hard to find a man  willing to take on a life like that.
She pauses and takes the reins from him.
Love isn't the only important thing.
Emmett rides up on Hannah's side and keeps pace beside th smiling at the sight of the couple.
How you doing, m'am? Getting enough  help?
Hannah, caught between the two men, smiles.
More than enough.
Have you thought at all about your  plans?
Some. I've been talking to the  Parkers. One thing I know I'm not  doing -- I'm not going back.
The wagon train splashes noisily across the river, driver yelling loudly to urge on their teams. Emmett, Paden, Mal and Jake, on horseback, direct the crossing.

The wagon train is moving through pretty, rolling country Mal rides up to join Emmett and Paden on point ahead of t train. In his hand is a yellowed letter. He points off to the south where a dramatic half-dome of rock towers above the hills.
This is it, gents. My ma told me to  head south past that rock.
Good luck, Mal.
Maybe we'll see you sometime.
(doesn't think so) Yeah... maybe. So long.
He rides away, and he doesn't look back.

A buckboard with a man and a young girl in it is stopped the fork, its two occupants standing up and waving excite As the wagon train pulls to a halt, Hobart climbs down fr the lead wagon and is embraced by the homesteader from th buckboard, BRADLEY. Bradley points off along the right fork of the road as he speaks to Hobart.
It's right down this road aways.  I'll ride in with you myself. (to the girl in the  buckboard) Carol, go spread the word our people  are here.
The girl, CAROL, whips the buckboard into motion and  disappears down the road. Bradley is looking down the lin of wagons.

I thought there'd be more of you.  But I thank the Lord for each and  every one. We'll have a solid strip  of bottomland under the plow when  you people stake your claims. (a grim look at Hobart) And we're going to need every hand  to hold it.
AT HANNAH'S WAGON. Emmett has brought his horse up to fac Hannah and, on horseback beside her wagon, Paden.
Hope to see you again, m'am.
She nods demurely.

I think I'll ride along with the  lady here. Just take a look at this  farmland before I come into Silverado.  See what makes a trip this hard worth  taking. (catches Emmett's  amused look) I'll see you around.
I'll be around.
AT THE LEAD WAGON. Hobart has what might be tears in his  eyes as he picks up the reins and looks at the countrysid
I feel like I've arrived in Canaan.
When we got here, we thought it was  Eden. And it's pretty close -- right  down to the serpents.
The wagon train moves out along the right fork of the roa as Emmett and Jake, waving goodbye, ride straight ahead t town.
Silverado is a sprawling, active, handsome frontier town, cattle center and supply station for the burgeoning silve mines to the west. Emmett and Jake ride into town.

Mal comes around the shoulder of a hill and reins to a ha He takes the yellowed letter from his pocket and checks a detail. He smiles at the stand of cottonwoods that marks route. After all these years, he's excited to be approach some kind of home. He hurries on.

The land office is in the front of the first floor of the Hollis home, a separate, two-story structure on a side st Now we're looking down the porch as KATE HOLLIS embraces brothers, Emmett and Jake. Her big, bear-like, gentle hus J.T., comes out to add his greetings. After the laying on hands, the attention of all four is drawn to the doorway a figure we cannot yet see. Now he steps shyly into view: eleven-year-old AUGIE. Jake makes a show of shaking Augie's hand, man to man. Emmett  kneels to greet him at eye level; the boy's grown a lot i five years.

Mal reaches the top of the hill, a look of high expectati on his face. But now he pulls up sharply, his expression  changing. Not what he expected. Down below in a pretty, little valley that recently embra a farm are hundreds of cattle, roaming free across the la remnants of the fields. And the burnt-out remains of a sm farmhouse.
Mal dismounts near the blackened timbers and walks into t ruins. He looks around in a daze: he's home, but there's home there.

head_text.subj: EXT. KNOLL ABOVE BRADLEY'S PLACE, (HOMESTEADER LAND)

text: Paden and Hannah are just reaching the top of the knoll. the distance below them is Bradley's farm, in the barnyar of which the wagon train has pulled up for this first nig
Mr. and Mrs. Parker have agreed to  join their parcel to mine. We'll  work them together. (she points) Mine starts right over there. It's  all I've ever wanted. Pretty land,  isn't it?
(nods, looking at her) And a pretty lady.
She turns to face him with a clear-eyed gaze that is almo scary.
A lot of men have told me that. Maybe  it's true. I guess some women are  slow to believe it.
Believe it.
They're drawn to me by that. But it  never lasts.
Why?
Because they don't like what I want.
What's that?
(turns back toward  her view) I want to build something, make things  grow. That takes hard work -- a  lifetime of it. That's not why men  come to a pretty woman.
He shakes his head, agreeing, though she cannot see it.
After a while, I won't be so pretty.  But this land will be.
She turns to face him again. He understands now as well a she that romance is not in their future. But friendship c be.
Hannah, don't tell me what you think  I want to hear.
Hannah laughs with him.

Mal has made a fire in the remains of the fireplace and i cooking food. As he sits back, he senses he is being watc He turns. There at the edge of the light stands an old bl man holding a Henry .44 rifle like Mal's -- his father, E JOHNSON. The two men look at each other a long time.
Daddy?
I saw the light. I thought maybe Rae  had come back to see me. But I never  thought it'd be my boy. I never  thought that.
Mal goes to him and encloses him in his arms.
Ma?
Ezra looks up at him and shakes his head.
She was sick for a long time. She  was sick when she wrote you, but she  didn't say it. I never thought you'd  come. But she did.
Mal takes it hard. They move back to the fire together.
Where is Rae?
She's gone, gone to town. She hated  working on the farm... (a bitter glance) ...just like you.
(gestures) What happened?
They run me off. They burned me out.  They made it so I couldn't do. Just  like Georgia. If you won't sell,  they take it anyway.
Who?
(as though it were  obvious) The cattle! This valley runs down to  a clear creek. That's why we picked  this spot, and that's why they don't  want us here.
You own this land.

I paid the government for it, all  right. That don't mean much out here. (he motions behind  him) Malachi, I'm living like a wildcat  in a cave in those hills. Hiding  out, afraid to walk my own land.
What about the law?
Whose law? The law here runs a man  down -- just like these cattle.
Mal thinks about that and grows very angry. Finally --
That ain't right and I've had enough  of what ain't right.

The group is finishing dinner in the kitchen/sitting room the back of the ground floor. Augie is tooting the carved whistle pipe that Emmett has given him. Kate and Emmett b to clear the dishes as Jake and J.T. continue to sit.
I thought running the land office  would be easy work, J.T., but it  sounds like what you got here ain't  much fun.

We got a bad situation here, and  those homesteaders you brought in  with you are going to make it worse. (indicates front of  house) When they come into this office to  stake their claims, I think it's  going to be the start of real trouble.  They're going to cut McKendrick off  on the north.

J.T.'s done everything he can. I  married a brave man. Augie, take  that delightful gift your uncle gave  you out of here while we're talking. (back to others) McKendrick picked the new sheriff  himself, so J.T. can't even get the  law enforced.
Half the gunslingers that drift into  town turn up on our police force.
A man could die of thirst before  anybody offered him a drink around  here.
J.T. pulls a bottle of whiskey from a cabinet and sets up three glasses, but Kate pantomimes for him to add one for her.
Maybe you all ought to come to  California with Jake and me. (across the room) How 'bout it, Augie, you want to go  with us?
Sure!
You know, Augie, there are no schools  in California.
(aglow) Really?
Augie's going to grow up here. There's  nothing wrong with the land, it's  just some of the people.
The problem is, Emmett, you killed  the wrong McKendrick.
Why, J.T., watch what you're saying  around Augie. Emmett didn't kill  anybody.
Well, Kate, it was self-defense sure  enough, but I think you'd have to  say I killed old Murdo. I think that's  definitely the word.
It was my fault.
It was not -- it was Murdo's. Those  McKendricks don't know how to act  like human beings.
His son is worse than he was. He's  smoother, so you don't always hear  him coming, but he'll do anything to  keep his range free.
(intensely) I'm worried what he's going to do  when he finds out you boys are back.
Emmett puts his arm around her.
I think Jake here can take care of  himself. I did five years I didn't  owe. McKendrick ought to be satisfied  with that and let it lie.
Kate looks between her brothers. She is not reassured.

Having smothered the fire, Mal mounts up, then reaches do to pull his father onto the horse behind him. They begin  picking their way through the cattle when two night-ridin cowboys, RED and SCRUFFY, approach through the gloom.
Is that you, Ezra?
(to his mate, jovially) You see pretty good, Red. Is there  one or two of them? (He laughs) What brings you out of your hole,  Johnson?
We're going to find that place one  of these days. Who you got with you,  Ezra?
This is my son. He's come home.
Ain't that sweet, Red? I'm afraid  you boys are trespassing on McKendrick  land.
You got it all wrong, mister. This  is our place.
What? Mr. McKendrick bought this  place from your father.
That's a lie.
Tomorrow we're going to town to  straighten that out once and for  all. The next day we'll be back  here... farming. And these cattle  better be gone.
The two cowboys are taken aback. They look to each other guidance.
If I find any cattle on our land  after tomorrow, I'm going to start  carving them into steaks. And believe  me, that's one thing I know about.
Killing cattle is a hanging offense  in these parts. If we shot you down  right now, we'd be within our rights.
Mister, you ever seen what a Henry  rifle can do in the hands of someone  who knows how to use it?
The two cowboys tense, their gun hands flexing.
Who would that be? You?

Behind Mal, Ezra lowers the barrel of his own Henry towar the cowboys and cocks it. He looks like a man coming back life. The two cowboys are dumbfounded. They turn and star to ride away. Scruffy shouts back at them --
This ain't the end of it!
(to Ezra) We're going to get your land back,  Daddy... our land.
(marvelling at events) Maybe we will! Maybe we will!  (pause) After all, I never thought I'd get  my son back.
Paden rides along the dark street, drawn irresistibly tow the thinking MUSIC, lights, and hubbub of the big saloon The Midnight Star.

Paden comes in and looks around with some pleasure. It's expansive place, busy now with gamblers, drinkers, and  brightly-dressed saloon girls. A piano player bangs away the corner. Paden has to smile. This is the way a saloon  ought to be. Now, even Paden is home. Paden walks up to stand at the bar. The BARTENDER is busy the far end of the bar. Paden is patiently waiting to get his attention when he hears a woman's voice behind him, o his side of the bar.
What can I do you for, stranger?
Paden turns to face his interlocutor, but at first cannot find her. After a moment, though, he looks down to see a  small woman in a velvet dress -- STELLA.
You work here?
I run the place. What can I get you?

She is already moving away toward the near end of the bar He watches her disappear around the end, then sees the to of her head appear behind the bar down there. As she move back toward him, she gets taller and taller, until she is facing him eye to eye across the bar.
Bourbon.
As she reaches under the bar and produces bottle and glas Paden leans over and peeks behind the bar. A foot-wide ra runs the length of it.
Nifty.
(smiles) The world is what you make of it,  friend. If it doesn't fit, you make  alterations.
I'll drink to that. Will you join  me, Miss --
Stella.
Paden.
Stella sets up a glass for herself, and they shake hands. Paden looks up at a carved ornamental star on the back wa over the words "The Midnight Star".
Stella... Are you the midnight star  herself?
I am. I'm always there, but I only  shine at night.
A saloon girl -- a lovely, young, black woman -- RAE pass with some drinks. Paden watches her go, then looks around the room.
My compliments to you, Miss Stella.  This is what I call a saloon.
Thanks. That's what I call it too.
And I know what I'm talking about.
You like a good saloon?
It's the only place I'm happy.
Me too. What's wrong with us?
Their eyes meet for a moment, and a real connection is ma
You wouldn't be needing any help  around here, would you? Maybe with  the gambling?
(points) You see that fellow over there in  the gray coat?
Paden nods, and now we see him too: a big man in some gam like finery -- KELLY. He is leaning over a poker game.
That's Kelly, my so-called partner.  He runs that side.
So-called?
Yeah, aside from being a loud-mouthed,  lying cheat, he's just the man I  would have picked.
Why'd you go into business with him?
I don't own this place. The man who  does stuck me with Kelly.
Who's the owner?
Here he comes right now.

Stella nods toward the door, and Paden turns to look. Cob enters through the swinging doors. He looks around with a proprietary air as he walks to the bar. He is almost ther before his gaze settles on Paden and Stella. He stops in tracks, and a big grin splits his face.
Well, look at this! Two of my favorite  people in the world, talking to each  other.
Cobb moves up and puts an arm around Paden as he shakes h hand. Stella is interested in this connection, but she do faze easily. Paden is the surprised one.
Stella, this is one of my oldest  surviving friends. Treat him right.
That was my plan.
(laughs) Oh, yeah, you two are going to get  along fine. You got a lot in common.
Cobb looks across the room and yells.
Kelly, get over here. (to Paden) You didn't come all this way just to  pay me back that money, did you? (turns to Kelly) Kelly, meet my friend Paden.
(cool) Howdy.
Give the man a line of credit. He  already owes the house thirteen bucks.
Kelly casts a wary, appraising glance over Paden, nods, a moves off.
You got a place to stay?
I just got to town.
Stella, we still got an extra room  out back, don't we?
It's not in use at the moment.
Cobb comes around the end of the bar to stand next to Ste
What brings you into my saloon?
Luck, I guess.
(cackles at this) Good old Paden. I was hoping you'd  changed your mind about the job.
You didn't tell me you owned a saloon.
Cobb looks at Paden a long time and laughs.
That ain't the half of it, friend.
He turns away, taking off his coat, and hangs it on a peg back there. When he turns back, rolling up his sleeves, o eyes are drawn to the same thing as Paden's: a shiny, sil sheriff's star.
Welcome to heaven.

Mal is asleep on some hay in the small cave his father ha fixed up as a hideout and home. A shadow falls across him Ezra stands looking at his son with loving eyes. In his h are a water bucket and his Henry rifle. Now he turns quie away.
Ezra emerges. From here, it would be impossible to tell t the cave was inhabited. Except that, on this morning, Mal horse is tied nearby. Ezra looks around cautiously and mo off into the rocks.
Ezra picks his way among the boulders warily.

Ezra comes out of the surrounding rocks and goes to the e of the spring. A stream runs off downhill from the pool. props the rifle against a rock and bends to drink from th spring. He hears something and turns quickly. What he see makes him reach for the rifle, but the sound of several G COCKING freezes him inches from it. There are four Cowboys, McKendrick's men, emerging from t hiding places. Their eyes search the surrounding rocks.  Scruffy and Red, the cowboys from the previous night, are there, but the leader is HOYT.
Where's the other one, Johnson?
Ezra is silent.
You couldn't leave well enough alone,  could you, old man? (resigned) Our orders are to run you two off.  If you tell us where your son is, we  won't have to do any shooting.
You're lying, Hoyt... like always.
Not this time. I got my orders.
Ezra thinks a moment, looks over at Scruffy, then back to Hoyt.
My son's on his way to town.
That's too bad. You'll have to go by  yourself.
The distant ROAR OF GUNS echoes in the small space. Mal a with a start. Did he dream it? He looks around.
Daddy?

Mal, rifle in hand and frantic, is lost among the rocks. he stops, listening. He hears HOOFBEATS. He scrambles to top of a boulder and looks down. WHAT HE SEES. The four Cowboys far below are riding away  from the base of the hill.

Mal comes out of the rocks. Ezra's rifle is no longer pro where he left it. Ezra is gone. Mal rushes to the edge of the spring, in agony. He looks around desperately, and th freezes. Ezra's dead body is floating away down the mountain strea Mal splashes into the water, tripping and sliding on the  slippery rocks. Finally, he is able to reach Ezra. Mal si in the water and hugs his father to him.
Only a few customers. Early light streams in over gamblin tables draped with dust covers. Stella is busy behind the bar. Paden and Emmett are nursing cups of coffee at a tab
Hannah's a smart, pretty woman, but  she's got a hard idea for living.
(doesn't follow) Yeah?
All I'm saying is, you won't trip  over me if you look her up.
(understands, but --) I'm going to California with my  brother.
Cobb comes in the swinging doors, heading for the bar. Pa waves him over.
Cobb, I want you to meet Emmett.  He's a friend of mine. (to Emmett) This is Sheriff Cobb.
(shaking hands) Pleased to meet you, Sheriff.
(interested) Pleasure is mine. Always happy to  meet a friend of Paden's. (yelling to Stella) Stella, bring Kelly out here, will  you?
Cobb turns back to Emmett with an odd smile on his face.
You're Kate Hollis' brother, aren't  you? (Emmett nods) You're the one who killed old Murdo  McKendrick.
Paden watches as the two men let that hang between them.
Didn't have much choice. He was about  to shoot my brother in the back.
Can't be having that now can we?
Stella appears with Kelly, who speaks to Cobb.
You wanted to see me?
We're going to make some adjustments.  I wanted you to be here when I offered  Paden your job. I think he could do  it without getting greedy. Stella  and I are tired of you skimming our  profits.
Stella is surprised. The charge is true, but she didn't k this was coming.
What are you talking about?
I'm done talking. Get out.
You can't do this.
(smiling) Really?

Without warning Cobb hits Kelly viciously in the stomach. Stella jumps. Cobb grabs the doubled-over Kelly by the ha and the belt, and propels him out of the saloon, letting before Kelly crashes through the swinging doors and into street. Cobb comes back toward the table as though nothin had happened.
How about it, Paden? You want the  job?
Paden, considering, glances at the still swinging doors.
I see you're an understanding boss.
Cobb chuckles, picks up Paden's coffee cup, and takes a s
Nothing like that will happen between  us.
Maybe we ought to ask Stella.
He turns toward her. She likes the idea.
You'd be welcome.
She is smiling at him warmly when suddenly her eyes shift her expression changes, and she screams --
No, Kelly! He'll kill you!

Cobb is already in motion. He spins, drawing his gun, and fires repeatedly at the swinging doors. Kelly has been ai over them and is blasted back into the street as the slat splinter. Cobb holsters his gun. The coffee cup is still his other hand. He takes a final sip, puts the cup down, licks a spilled drop off his thumb. Stella is repulsed. Cobb fixes her with a malevolent look and his tone is icy --
Thanks for warning me.
Stella rushes out to the street, as Emmett and Paden get Emmett and Cobb are very close for one moment.
Didn't have much choice.
They go out through the gathering crowd.
Down the street a stagecoach is rolling into town. Cobb s off the porch to kneel beside Kelly's body. He looks acro at the already-kneeling Stella.
I never enjoy killing a man.

Stella stands, so for a moment she is taller than he. She stalks back into the saloon. The stagecoach has pulled up across the street. A tall, l gambler has disembarked and now walks toward the saloon,  carrying his heavy satchel. He moves through the assemble people until he is standing over Kelly's body. This is SL
Excuse me, Sheriff. I'm a gambler  who would like to run an honest game  in your town. To whom do I speak  about that? (glances down) I hope it's not this gentleman.
Cobb likes his style. He smiles and turns to indicate Pad
That's him.
Paden and Cobb exchange looks for a second. Then Cobb is  bustling off.
I gotta get somebody to clean up  this mess.
Emmett and Paden watch Cobb move down the street.
You used to ride with that guy?
Paden looks at Emmett, then down at Kelly.

Jake unhitches the pinto and begins to lead it away. Sudd Augie appears from nowhere on the back porch, jumps up to the railing, and leaps out toward the pinto's back -- jus as Jake did in the escape from Turley. But Augie misses a lands in the dirt. Jake, irritated, watches the child dus himself off.
What're you doing? I told you to  practice with a horse that's not  moving.
Jake turns and starts away. Augie runs after him.
Where you going?
I got things to do, kid. I'm a busy  man.
I'll go with you.
(stops, looks at him) A grown man can't have a little boy  with him everywhere he goes.
Jake walks away. Augie watches, then yells --
Who's a grown man?

Stella works at the spigots of some large kegs, filling e bottles with a portion of whiskey, diluting them with wat and corking them. Paden comes in and watches her. She han him a bottle to cork and starts the process again as he s it.
Is this a fair mix?
I'm saving lives here. The straight  stuff would raise a blood blister on  boot leather.
I meant, seemed like a lot of whiskey.
They share a smile. Paden takes down a fancier bottle fro shelf, examining the label.
What's this?
That's the good stuff.
Oh, yeah? How good?
She understands him and produces two glasses with a grin.
(pouring the drinks) Here's to the good stuff.
Stella lifts her glass, sealing the bond.
May it last a long time.
Before they can drink, the Bartender bursts in.
You better get out here.

The room is crowded but silent, frozen. Near the middle o the bar the sexy, young, saloon girl, PHOEBE, stands  frightened between Jake and Tyree, the mean fellow we saw released at Chimayo -- now a deputy for Sheriff Cobb. The two men appear about to draw.
Nothing happened, Tyree. This is my  job.
Shut up.
I don't believe a lady has to explain  anything to a man this ugly.

Slick watches from a card table nearby, with Rae standing beside him. Now his hand drops casually from the curve of her rear to the vicinity of his boot. Paden and Stella come up on opposite sides of the bar, hi in front. Paden sees everything in the room: Tyree's frie Deputies Kyle and GARTH, are behind Jake and clearly pois to kill him if Tyree fails.
What's the problem here?
(with venom) Stay out of it, Paden.
He can't do that, Tyree. Cobb's hired  him.
That's Cobb's mistake.
Come out of there, Phoebe. You've  done enough.

As Phoebe starts to move from between the men, Tyree grab her viciously by the arm. In the instant of that movement Paden's hand flashes out and draws Tyree's Colt out of it holster from behind. Garth and Kyle tense as Tyree whirls Paden, eyes flaming. But his own gun is pointed at his ch
Get out of here, Jake.
All I did was kiss the girl.
That's what you said in Turley. You  remember how that ended.
What's the matter, Paden? You afraid  I couldn't get those two behind me?
I don't want you getting anyone in  my place.
Jake looks at Paden, who motions him out with the gun. Ja starts to move grudgingly, but first flashes Phoebe a big "see you later" look. He goes out.
(to Paden) I should have killed you a long time  ago.
Paden flips the gun in his grasp and hands it to Tyree, b first.
Why not now?

The situation is now totally reversed, and no one can qui believe it. Tyree cocks the gun. At the poker table Slick lifts his pant leg, revealing the handle of a custom-made dagger secreted in his boot.
Don't do it, Tyree. I just lost a  partner. If you kill him, I'll never  get anyone to work here.
