Tyree considers for a moment, then holsters his gun. To S
Better start looking.
He goes out. Garth and Kyle follow. Phoebe hurries away f Stella's hard look. Slick relaxes. The piano kicks in. Pa leans against the bar toward Stella.
You really are a gambler.
Give me some of the good stuff.

A door opens on the upstairs porch and Rae emerges, giggl and buttoning her dress. A hand reaches out and pulls her back inside for another squealing embrace. She pushes her free and comes outside again, then starts down the exteri stairs. She is almost to the bottom when she stops sudden Mal stands at the bottom of the stairs. They look at each other a long time. Conflicting emotions race across Rae's face, but the winner is cold anger.
Hello, Rae.
What are you doing here? I thought  you were done with our family.
Daddy's dead.
Rae seems to sway, then sits down on the stairs above Mal For a moment she is somewhere else, but when she returns, her look is as hard as before.
He was murdered.
Who did it?
I'm not sure, but I got an idea. And  when I am sure, they're going to  pay.
(bitter) Oh that's just fine. Where were you  when Ma and Daddy needed you? It's  too late, Mal. Now you finally show  up and all you can think of is to  get yourself killed.
Now Slick comes down the stairs behind Rae, pulling on hi jacket. Mal glares at him; this is who can buy his sister now.
Are you all right, Rae?
Yeah, I'm okay.
Slick seems unperturbed by Mal's glare. To Rae --
Will you introduce me to your friend?
He's not my friend. He used to be my  brother.
(offers his hand to  Mal) Calvin Stanhope... but my mother  called me Slick.
Mal just looks at the proffered hand. Slick retracts it  without offense.
I know what you're thinking, mister,  but I think Rae's a special lady.  Excuse me.
Slick comes down past Mal and moves off. Mal watches him then turns to Rae.
What are you doing here, Rae? This  ain't for you.
It's none of your business.
Rae, all we got is each other.
(standing up) I don't have any family any more.
She brushes past him and is gone.
Carol, Bradley's daughter, and a Friend are playing on th roof of the farmhouse, above the noisy activity of the  welcoming celebration. Now Bradley steps into the foregro
Don't fall off of there, you fools!
Might do them some good, Daniel. I  wasn't worth a damn until I fell off  the barn on my head.

The two men turn to look at the dancing. It's a festive s all around: tables are laden with food near a large bonfi a few of the covered wagons are pulled up nearby, childre dart about before the pick-up band of musicians. Now we see, here among the sodbusters, whirling by with a comely lass, Jake, looking mighty slim without his double gunbelt. He and his partner glide by Emmett, who stands  shouting over the din with Hannah and Mr. and MRS. PARKER
Hannah's the hardest-working gal I  ever saw.
It's going to be all right.
I wish you the best, Mrs. Parker.
Mr. Parker twirls his wife off into the dance. Emmett and Hannah, a slightly awkward couple, stroll away from the m This is the first time Emmett has seemed less than certai
The Parkers seem like nice folks.
They've been kind to me.
(after a few steps) Paden sends his best.
(smiles) I guess I put a good scare into him.
Emmett smiles in agreement.
I'm surprised to see you out here  tonight.
I just came out to say goodbye.
(stopped) Goodbye?
Yeah, me and Jake will be heading  out for California soon.
Hannah is silent for a moment. She sits down at one of th tables and looks at him. For the first time there is a  softness in her voice.
You came all the way out here to  tell me you're going to California?  All you had to do was go, and we'd  never see each other again.
That's why I'm here.
She gives him an odd look, a soft challenge to his retice
Why?
He sits down beside her and looks at his boots.
You don't make it easy on a fellow.
Didn't Paden tell you that?
Emmett smiles at that and looks into her lovely eyes. Aft a long moment --
Maybe you thought you'd be back this  way someday.
Yeah... that must have been it.

UP ON THE ROOF of the farmhouse, Carol is yelling and  gesturing to her oblivious father below, while her Friend stares frozen into the night. Jake is wiping his brow as he stands at the edge of the  dancers. He looks up at Carol quizzically. Only now do we hear it, over the din of the music: the TH of hooves. Out of the night, streaming around the farm  buildings, comes a horde of masked Cowboys, McKendrick's  men. They send up a horrible yell and begin firing their  weapons in the air. Their arrival is so sudden that the celebrants are frozen their places, mothers hugging children to them, men far f their weapons. There are SCREAMS. Emmett grabs a panicked child from the path of the horses and moves back, passing her to Hannah. He's trying to gau his response in the midst of all these innocents. Two Cowboys have roped opposite ends of a section of fenc and now pull the deadly drag, already thick with ravaged  corn, through the barnyard, knocking over everything in i path. Jake slides through the chaos toward his gunbelt, hung on peg on the barn wall. A Cowboy pulls the gate from the pigsty, and the pigs squ out. Another Cowboy begins shooting them with a Henry rif On the roof, Carol looks in horror at the death of her pr sow. Emmett is herding as many Settlers as he can toward the c of the barn. Bradley edges toward the door of his farmhouse. Hobart is urging some women between two wagons. A Cowboy  rides by and kicks him viciously. Hoyt pulls up, looks around, then gestures to some of his men. Two Cowboys with prepared torches in their hands rid up to the bonfire and swing low, lighting their firebrand One moves ahead toward the farmhouse, reins his horse, an heaves the torch high in the air toward the roof on which the two children perch. In the air, the tumbling flame suddenly explodes at the R of a shotgun. Sparks shower harmlessly to the ground. Bradley has shot it out of the air with one barrel of his shotgun. The blast has created a momentary, shocked lull the attack. Bradley looks wild. Emmett watches, fearful. His hand is on his gun. Hoyt looks at Bradley. Bradley swings the shotgun around  toward the other torch-bearer. The Cowboy who tossed the first torch shoots Bradley dead Carol screams. Emmett looks across the yard at Jake, who steps out from cowering homesteaders, a gun in each hand. Emmett draws a kills the man who shot Bradley. Now all the Settlers hit dirt. Jake fires from both hands repeatedly. One Cowboy dies an another takes it in the arm. The man who was shooting the pigs swings his rifle around toward Jake, and Emmett kill him with one shot. Hoyt reacts big to the presence of deadly wolves in the m of these sheep. He peers through the tumult, trying to se their faces. His Cowboys are shooting wildly into the cro now, but he rides through them, signalling a retreat. Emmett jumps from the top of a fence to the roof of the h the Henry rifle in his hand. He scrambles to the peak of roof, where the two children still cower. Bracing the rif on the chimney, he takes careful aim. Once... twice... he fires. One Cowboy dead, one wounded and fleeing. Hannah runs up to the riderless horse of a fallen Cowboy pulls a rifle from its scabbard. She cocks it and fires o at the retreating Cowboys. Jake mounts a horse Pony Expre style and rides out of the barnyard.

LATER. Emmett lowers a weeping Carol to the ground. The g rushes toward her fallen father and her mother, who cradl the body. Hobart intercepts the girl, trying to shield he from the sight. Emmett's eyes meet Hobart's. Hobart lets  Carol go. Emmett walks through the devastation to where Hannah stan dazed, rifle still in hand. Emmett puts his arm around he She jumps at his touch, then moves against him. Jake ride into the barnyard and up to Emmett. He is flushed.
There's two more out there walking  home, if they can walk.

Emmett's gaze is caught by something across the barnyard. Hannah follows his gaze. Mr. Parker stumbles out of the darkness at the side of th barn, sobbing. Hannah breaks from Emmett and rushes to Mr Parker. When she is beside him, she freezes, staring into the shadows. Emmett watches.

Augie is standing circus-style on the saddle of the pinto he rides down the alley. As he approaches the main street his foot slips, and he bumps down hard into the saddle. T horse is barely in his control as he bounces out into the busier thoroughfare, and into the path of -- An imposing  phalanx of four horsemen: Hoyt, Scruffy, SWANN, and their boss, ETHAN MCKENDRICK. The pinto shies as the horsemen p up abruptly.
Sorry 'bout that.
Swann looks with interest at the pinto, then reaches out grabs the reins from Augie's hand.
Hey!
Where'd you get this horse, kid?
This is my uncle's horse.
The hell it is.
(irritable) What's the problem, Swann?
Emmett steps off the sidewalk on the other side of the st and approaches the group, his eyes on McKendrick.
Yeah, what's the problem?
McKendrick turns at the sound of Emmett's voice. Somethin powerful flicks through his eyes, but not too many people would see it.
Emmett.
McKendrick.
Hoyt eyes Emmett, who seems familiar. Emmett looks at Swa in such a way that Swann releases the reins of the pinto.
I didn't know you were out.
Did it seem short to you?
McKendrick reacts to Emmett's tone.
That's all over as far as I'm  concerned, Emmett. I'm satisfied.
Sounds good.
All right then. (to his men) Let's go.
Mr. McKendrick, don't you recognize  that pinto?
(doesn't) What?
That's Lee's horse.
Shut up, Swann.
Now McKendrick understands. He avoids Emmett's gaze and s to Swann.
Forget it.
Wait a minute. Get down off of there,  Augie.

Augie hops down as Emmett takes the reins. Emmett gives A a look and a small nod, and the boy steps away. Emmett looks once again at the distinctive brand on the  pinto's flank, a circle with two wavy lines beneath it. N he leads the pinto around beside McKendrick's horse so he can see the brand on that animal. McKendrick has to twist his saddle to watch Emmett. The brands are the same. Emme looks up at McKendrick. Things are clear between them.
The man who lost this horse must  have been working for you. I should  have known. But you changed your  brand, Ethan.
McKendrick's tone is different now --
A lot of things changed when my father  died.

Emmett lays the reins of the pinto across the front of  McKendrick's saddle, but they might just as well be a  gauntlet. McKendrick picks them up. He and his men move d the street. Emmett walks over and takes Augie beneath his arm. DOWN THE STREET. Hoyt rides close to McKendrick but looks back over his shoulder.
Mr. McKendrick, he was one of them  last night at Bradley's.
McKendrick reacts: more bad news.

J.T. supervises the newly-arrived Settlers as they file t homestead claims. There is a battle-weary but resolved ai to the group after the night attack. They are going to st it out. The last step in the filing process is to sign in large register. Mr. Parker signs and moves away. Hannah s up for her turn. Her face is a little harder today, but h hand is steady.

Several of the Settlers' wagons are here, guarded by vigi armed men. Their attitude has become more wary, siege-lik Parker climbs onto a wagon. Hannah is about to follow whe Emmett approaches with Augie, who runs off around the hou Several of the Settlers greet Emmett warmly. Emmett looks closely at Hannah's face.
Are you all right?
This is a brutal land.
You must have known that before you  came.
It's one thing to know it...
She looks off, then bitterly --
We told Sheriff Cobb about the attack. (with an edge) He said he'd... look into it. (Emmett understands) I can't believe he's the law out  here. Now I see why you all wear  guns.
How's Mr. Parker doing?
Just like you'd think. But he's not  going to run. We're sticking to our  plan. Now we both need help.
Emmett looks her over. He's not liking her any less.
Cobb sits with his boots up on his desk. McKendrick sits the shadows across the room.
He must be pretty good.
He's good, all right. Too good for  my men. That's why you've got to  take care of it.
What about his brother?
We'll handle that. He's careless.
Cobb looks out the window.
Things are getting messy around here. (he looks at McKendrick) I hear Ezra Johnson got himself  killed.
I heard that too.
Did you hear his son is still around?
McKendrick reacts to that, and Cobb can't suppress a smil McKendrick sees it and stands up.
Cobb, looks like you're finally going  to earn your money.
Stella and Cobb have been dividing the receipts between t Cobb puts another sum in a leather pouch.
This'll be for Paden.
Stella is impressed by the amount. Cobb notes her reactio
It's an advance. We want him to know  he's going to be happy here.
I wouldn't worry about that.
I thought you two would get along.
Cobb opens the office door and holds it for Stella.
Cobb and Stella come out into the saloon, which is not ye crowded. Stella moves up her ramp behind the bar as Cobb  walks along in front of it.
From what I've seen, Paden doesn't  care much about money.
He says he doesn't care about  anything, but he does. There's just  no telling what it's going to be.
Slick is standing at the bar. Cobb settles in next to him They nod at each other.
Howdy, Mr. Slick.
Sheriff.
Cobb turns to Stella, who has put a bottle before him and pouring Cobb and herself drinks. Cobb seems to be includi Slick in the following story, though he addresses Stella.

Let me tell you about your friend  Paden. Me and him and Tyree and a  few other boys did a good bit of  riding together a few years back.  Business, you know, and business was  pretty good. We were moving around a  lot, the way you have to in that  work, and somewhere along the line  we picked up this dog. One of the  boys took to feeding it, so it  followed us everywhere. Anyway, this  one time we were leaving a little  Missouri town in quite a hurry, with  a bunch of the locals on our tails.  The dog somehow got tangled up with  Tyree's horse and Tyree went flying.  Tyree was pretty mad when he jumped  up, so he shot the dog. Didn't kill  him, though. Before you know it,  Paden's off his horse and holding  the dog. He'd gone all strange on  us. Said we should go on without  him. I thought he was kidding at  first. But he wasn't. Tyree was ready  to plug 'em both. And all this with  the posse coming down on us. Here I  thought we were pals after all that  riding. And suddenly he's more worried  about a mutt. So we did like he asked  and left him. He went to jail for a  dog.
Stella has been listening intently. Now her glance shifts Paden has walked up beside Cobb. Cobb lifts his glass to  Paden with a grin, but speaks to Stella.
And you want to hear the funny part?  Paden didn't even like the damn dog.
Paden gives Cobb an odd glance but smiles.
It evened out in the end. They locked  me up, but the dog sprung me.
Cobb and Slick laugh, but Stella just watches Paden.
Where's the dog now?
He left me.
Cobb takes the bottle and a couple glasses.
C'mon, Paden, I'll buy you a drink.
Cobb leads Paden to a table in the corner. As Paden sits  down, Cobb drops the pouch on the table. Paden glances at the contents as Cobb pours the drinks.
I took out thirteen dollars.
This is a lot of money.
I told you this was a sweet set-up.
It is that.
Maybe you could run it without Stella.
Paden looks sharply at Cobb. With some heat --
This is her life. I'll go before she  does.
Cobb is amused but not surprised.
Easy, boy. Just an idea.
Well, thanks, but forget it.

You know, Paden, what makes all this  work is me doing my job. The fellows  you came to town with are causing  some trouble. It's going to take a  little straightening out. I have my  responsibilities. I want you to  understand. It has nothing to do  with us.
Paden looks at Cobb a long time, then at his drink.
What is it you want from me?
Nothing. Do nothing. Don't get between  us.
I'm a great believer in doing nothing.
So we understand each other?
Don't worry about me. If you're taking  on Emmett, the last place I want to  be is between you.

We move along the burnished barrel of the old Henry .44 r to Emmett's eye, sighting along its length. Now we see his target. In the distance is a small cactus  plant. Emmett squeezes off a shot. The cactus does not mo He aims again and fires quickly. Again, nothing at the ca AT THE CACTUS. Now we're right behind the target plant, E in the distance. When he fires, a thin needle at the top  edge of the plant is blown away, the bullet leaving a sha trough in the green skin. He fires again, and the next ne disappears. Now there are four troughs. He's been hitting from the start. Emmett lowers the rifle, walks back to his horse tied nea and leaves the rifle, then moves away from the horse agai He stops, looking at a can in the dust fifty feet away. H shakes the fingers of his gun hand once, then very quickl he draws his Colt and fires. The can jumps into the air.  While it is still moving, Emmett holsters the gun, releas it, then draws again and fires. As the can jumps once mor Emmett repeats the action. Six times he draws. The can do stop moving until after the last shot. The horrible NOISE echoes away as Emmett holds the empty before him. From behind a rock ahead of him, Deputy Garth appears.
You're empty, mister.

Emmett immediately begins to bolt toward his horse. A las settles around his arms and whips him viciously backwards In a second he is back on his feet and running like a bul toward Deputy Kyle, who has stepped from the brush to thr the rope. Immediately a second lasso catches Emmett from other side and pulls taut. A deputy on horseback, CHARLIE has roped him. Charlie and Kyle pull their ropes, yanking Emmett onto his back. Now appearing around a bend in the arroyo is Tyree, a nas glint in his eye. He rides hard directly toward Emmett. E watches the pounding hooves approach. He struggles but ca move. Tyree's horse thunders over him, one hoof catching side with a sickening THUD. Emmett writhes in agony. Tyree turns his horse and heads back. Kyle pulls harder o his rope. Tyree rides over Emmett again, but we can't see the damage for the dust. Tyree walks his horse over and l down, as Garth, Kyle, and Charlie converge. Emmett's head is bleeding, his body crumpled. But he look up at them through pain-squinted eyes.
Ain't you dead yet, mister?
Cobb said he'd be hard to kill.
They all laugh at this.
(to Emmett) Guess you couldn't hear us coming. (to the others) He was practicing so hard for a fight,  he missed the whole thing.
The others cackle. Garth draws his gun.
So long, stranger.
He starts to lower the muzzle toward Emmett. There is the echoing CRACK of a shot and the gun flies from Garth's  shattered hand. Mal stands on a rock above them, his rifle pointed.
I don't want to kill you, and you  don't want to be dead. Drop your  guns.
The other deputies exchange glances as Garth bends in pai
He can't be that good, Tyree.
Do you want to find out?
(dropping his rope) I think we should do like he says.
As the others start to unbuckle their holsters, Charlie, compliant one, draws on Mal. Mal shoots him out of the sa dead. The others freeze.

Mal comes into view, leading a motley remuda. Emmett is t onto his horse, unconscious. The four deputies' riderless horses are strung along behind. All their guns have been  tied on Emmett's horse. Now Mal releases the extra horses and shoos them away. He leads Emmett's horse up the trail into the hills.
Emmett and Mal's horses are tied near the entrance.
Mal has tended to Emmett's head wound and now binds a lar ugly bruise on his ribs. Emmett, half-conscious, writhes pain, and now his eyes flicker open. Confused, he makes a futile attempt to rise.
...Gotta go...
Sure.
Emmett passes out again.
The three surviving deputies, gunless, trudge along the r Garth holds his wounded hand close to his body.
Emmett lies sleeping in the flickering light of the fire. Mal sits nearby, his Henry rifle lying at his feet. He is examining the Henry that Emmett had at the arroyo. Emmett wakes up, wincing.
Where are we?
Someplace safe. How you feeling?
Emmett's look makes it clear -- "bad".
I'd be worse if you hadn't come along.

I didn't just come along. I was  looking for you. (Emmett doesn't  understand) Jake said you were out there. I saw  him in town, and he told me about  that business the other night. Said  you boys took a Henry off one of  McKendrick's men. I wanted to see  it.
That's it.
Mal looks at the rifle in his arms sadly.
This was my father's. The men who  killed him took it.
(looks at him a moment) I'm sorry.
Emmett tries to move his pain-racked body.
I gotta get to my brother. If they  came after me, they'll want him too.
You'll never make it.
(still trying) Have to.
Mal reaches out with a strong hand and eases Emmett back  down.
I'll go. I'll bring Jake out here.
(after a long look) Be careful. You're in it now. And  it's gonna get mean.
So far that's all I seen in this  life.

It's quiet here, nobody around. We move up to the hay-loa window at the loft level. Now Jake dives into view, leapi from the hayloft to a beam and flipping completely around it. We hear GIGGLES. Phoebe climbs the ladder onto the lo and looks in wonder at her manic companion, who now flies back onto the loft. They look at each other with hungry  anticipation.

Mal, on foot, makes his way cautiously through the gloom the end of the alley. He looks over at the Hollis home an land office, windows aglow. Now Mal spots a Cowboy down t street smoking a cigarette as he leans against a hitching post. Mal is peering at him uncertainly when the front do of the Hollis house opens, and Kate steps out onto the po The Cowboy steps quickly back into the shadows, and Mal n it. Kate vigorously shakes a tablecloth over the railing and  turns back inside, talking as she goes.
Augie, I've had enough of this. Kiss  your father and get in bed.
She closes the door behind her. Mal sees the cowboy calle Red coming down the street and hurries away in the direct he came from. Red comes up to the WATCHING COWBOY.
No sign of him yet? ("no") He ain't at the saloon either.
Where is that boy?

Rae is finishing her evening's makeup in the cracked mirr of her cramped, little room. Mal slides in the door behin her, closing it quickly. He carries his rifle. She sees h reflection and stiffens but continues making up.
Get out. We have nothing to talk  about.
Rae, I need help.
Why come to me?
Because you're my sister. There's  nobody else. (a beat) The men who killed Daddy are after  Jake. I gotta talk to him.
What's stopping you?
They're watching the Hollis place. I  can't get through.
What makes you think I could?
Why would they stop you?
(bitter irony) Because I'm your sister.
Mal sits down on her bed. She looks at him a moment.
Wait here.
Stella is working behind the bar. Slick is playing poker a table nearby. Now Rae appears and whispers in his ear. throws in his cards, gets up, and follows her toward the  stairs. Stella watches.
Mal looks up as the door opens, then stands up when he se that Rae has brought Slick with her.
Why him?
Shut up. You need help, don't you?
We are looking up at the church steeple from across the  square. Now Slick steps into the foreground, looks around and waves someone on from behind. Mal comes into the fram
(quietly) Jake said he'd meet you behind the  church. Be careful. They're all over  the place.
Mal's opinion of Slick has softened. He offers his hand.
Thanks.
(shakes hands) Good luck.
Mal looks around, then slips away toward the church. Slic stands and watches.
Mal comes around the corner of the building. Cobb is loun comfortably on the back steps. Mal aims his rifle, but Co doesn't move.
You must be Ezra Johnson's boy.
Mal cocks the hammer.
Don't shoot the sheriff. It's against  the law.
Three deputies appear quietly out of the shadows behind M their guns pointed. The door behind Cobb opens, revealing Garth, his hand bandaged. Mal lowers the rifle.
So's killing a deputy.
Tyree comes up behind Mal and takes the rifle from his ha Suddenly he hits him in the kidney with the rifle butt. M goes down.
We're going to give you a fair  trial...
Garth has come down the steps and over to Mal. He holds h bandaged hand out in front of him, then kicks Mal vicious
...followed by a first-class hanging.
Finally Cobb gets up and walks over to look down at Mal.
Or you can ride out of here before  dawn.
Mal turns his head so he can look up at Cobb.
All you gotta do is tell me where to  find your friend Emmett.

Rae is serving drinks at a table in the noisy saloon. She sees Slick come in. Their eyes meet, but he goes to the b and orders a drink. She hurries over there. Slick throws  back a shot and turns to her, upset.
Did your brother tell you he killed  a deputy?
Rae is taken aback.
Jake never showed up. Sheriff Cobb  arrested Mal. Took him off to jail.
Rae begins to crack. Slick takes her into his arms. Stell moves up behind the bar, looking closely at Rae.
What's going on here, Rae?

Close on Mal as he dabs at a split lip with the tail of h shirt. He's sitting on a cot in a cell. He has been beate more. As the door to the outer office clangs open, he rea with resignation; here comes more pain. But when he looks up, it is Paden standing outside the bars. Behind Paden,  Garth throws a hostile look at Mal and goes out. Paden no Mal's condition. Mal regards Paden coolly.
Why are they doing this, Mal?
Because they enjoy it.
I heard from Stella you were trying  to find Jake. What happened to Emmett?
You don't know?
Paden takes the rebuke and shakes his head "no".
Cobb's men just about killed him.  That's what happened.
Paden reacts.
I got there just short of too late.
(pained) Lucky.
Mal snorts derisively at that and glances around.
Yeah, it's working out real good.
Where's Emmett now?
Mal gives him a disbelieving look.
You're working for Cobb these days,  aren't you?
Paden grimly acknowledges that.
Your friends have been beating me to  find that out. You think I'm gonna  just tell you?
Mal gets up to face Paden, separated by only a few inches and the steel bars.
You waltzed in here pretty easy, and  you can go out the same way. (motions him away) Me they're figuring to carry out.
Paden knows that no explanation will suffice here. Sadly, turns away from his former riding companion and leaves.
Rae waits nervously behind the noisy saloon, peering into the darkness. Now she sees what she's been waiting for: P comes out of the shadows. His mind elsewhere, it takes hi moment to focus on Rae.
Is he all right?
(considers a moment) It looks bad, Rae. He's a hard man,  and he won't give them what they  want. It's gonna cost him.
Can't you stop them?
I don't think so.
Rae begins to cry quietly and leans against a wall. Phoeb appears from the other direction and goes up to Rae.
Rae? It's Phoebe.
Jake has put his horse in the little corral behind the Ho house. He whistles as he goes up onto the back porch and the door.
There is one, dim lamp burning in the room. Jake sails hi hat across the room onto a hook, picks up a match, and li a second lamp. He calls out softly.
Kate?
He picks up the lamp and moves toward the dark office at front of the house and the stairs which lead upstairs. He steps through the door and freezes. A cocked six-gun appe near his ear.

In the light of Jake's lamp he sees: four masked men have Kate, J.T., and Augie gagged and held at gunpoint. The li boy is in his nightshirt. For one long moment Jake seems be considering a play. McKendrick is the one with the gun Jake's head.
Don't.
Rae has been tearfully telling Phoebe her story as Paden  stands nearby.
Looking for Jake? Jake's been with  me all evening. I just left him.
(suddenly alert) Where is he now?
He went home.
Paden takes off running into the darkness. Phoebe looks a him, confused. Rae grabs her by the shoulders.
All evening? Even after Slick came?
Slick?
Rae begins to understand an awful truth.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF HOLLIS HOUSE

text: A masked man (Hoyt) steadies Jake, hands bound behind his back, on one of the horses Red and the Watching Cowboy ha brought up to the front of the house. Another of the men  (Scruffy) is just coming out onto the porch.
Inside only two masked men remain, McKendrick and Swann.  J.T. watches them with hostile eyes. Swann notices Kate  peering out the window at Jake.
Take a long look, lady. It's the  last you'll see of him.
Shut up.

McKendrick has been looking thoughtfully at the ledgers a records shelved around the land office. Now he picks up t lamp Jake brought into the room. It lights his eyes above the bandana mask. They lock with J.T.'s . McKendrick heav the lamp into the shelves. Kerosene flames engulf the led McKendrick starts to move toward the door. J.T. snaps. He picks up a heavy register book and hurtles with enormous force, hitting McKendrick in the back of th head and knocking him down. J.T. dives for McKendrick's g Kate watches in terror, then sees Swann point his gun at scrambling J.T. She grabs Swann's arm, and his gun fires  into the floor. J.T. comes up with McKendrick's gun and fires quickly at  Swann, who has thrown off Kate. Swann, hit in the shoulde crashes back through a window and out onto the porch.
Jake reacts in anguish and twists in his saddle. Hoyt poi a cocked gun at him.

Scruffy, back at the door now, fires twice into J.T., sla his big body backward against the base of a counter. Kate's scream is muffled by her gag. Augie, eyes wide, da to his father's body, but rather than embrace him, he pri the gun from J.T.'s fingers and raises it toward Scruffy. Kate sees what's happening and leaps at Scruffy. He vicio pistol-whips her. Her unconscious, falling body knocks th gun from Augie's hand. McKendrick is straightening now, his head clearing. His  bandana has fallen from his face. He looks in horror at t wounded Hollises. Augie stares at his revealed face. Scruffy's gun is cocked and pointed at Augie.
Stop it!
He saw you.
McKendrick hates the way it's gone.
Bring him with us.

Paden runs up. Down the street in front of the Hollis hou a mass of men and horses, lit by the growing flames, thun away into the night. Paden races toward the house, as  neighbors rush about raising the alarm.
Paden runs up to the open front door and is momentarily  stopped by the heat.
In among the flames a bleeding Kate is desperately trying drag J.T.'s inert bulk to the door. Paden reaches her, pi her up, and runs out. Two neighbors pass him on their way J.T.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF HOLLIS HOUSE

text: A chaotic scene as the fire-fighting is organized. Severa Neighbor Women help Paden ease Kate down on a blanket.
Help J.T.!
Where's Augie? (to Paden) Her boy must be upstairs!
Paden rises as if to go back in, but stops at --
No, no... they took him. They took  my Augie.
Paden reacts to this, then turns as the two neighbors lay J.T.'s body nearby.

Word of the fire has not reached here, and normal, noisy  activity reigns. Slick is dealing a three-man poker game. Rae watches him from across the room, then takes a drink  over to him. When she places it before him, he looks up  appreciatively, then goes back to his game. She puts her  arms around him from behind and kisses his neck, then sli sensuously into the empty seat beside him. He ignores her adoring look and roaming hands, but smiles as he plays. BENEATH THE TABLE. Rae's left hand roves excitingly high Slick's thigh. Now, so smooth and quick we barely see it, her right hand lifts his trouser leg and slips the custom made dagger from his boot. Slick deals a hand. Rae watches him thoughtfully. The swi doors behind them crash open, and a TOWNSMAN bursts in.
Fire! The land office is on fire!
Most of the patrons rush out, including the players in Sl game, who grab their chips first. Slick peeks at one of t thrown-down hands out of curiosity, then rises slowly.
Shall we take a look?
Rae nods, and when she rises to take his arm, her hands a empty.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF HOLLIS HOUSE

text: The townspeople have formed a bucket brigade in a losing  battle with the fire at the Hollis house. SHOUTS fill the air above the ROAR of the inferno. Stella is among the new arrivals from the saloon. She is  stopped by the sight of Kate, bloody and hysterical, bein borne away. Horrified by the scene, Stella now snaps out it and begins YELLING ORDERS to the saloon patrons to hel fight the blaze. Paden is only a few feet from the flames, at the head of bucket line. He is in shirt sleeves, sweaty and sooty. Th heat of the fire is driving the line back. The Townsman n to Paden yells to him --
There's no way! It's a goner!

Cobb, Tyree, and Kyle appear from the shadows. Cobb takes the scene and spots J.T. being carried across the street. motions Tyree over to investigate, then moves toward the  fire. Slick and Rae arrive within the light of the blaze. Slick watches with detached interest, but Rae's gaze quickly lo on Cobb moving through the chaos. She sees him now with n eyes. Phoebe, crying, watches as J.T.'s limp body is hurried of on a stretcher, DR. SKINNER in attendance. She turns and face to face with Tyree, who grasps her arms. She regards him with revulsion and fear, then breaks from him and run off. Cobb moves up next to Paden.
Give it up.
Paden glances at him, then throws more water on. But now bucket line slows to a halt. The townspeople fade back a  little to watch the inevitable.
I hate to see this kind of thing in  my town.
Paden glares at Cobb, who is watching the fire.
I'm going to have to look into this.
Yeah, maybe I will too.
(looks at him) I thought we talked about that.
We didn't talk about this. (a beat, indignant) They took the little boy, Cobb.

Paden moves off toward a nearby hitching post, where he h left his gunbelt and hat. Cobb looks after him a moment,  then follows. They are now a short distance from the  onlookers. Paden straps on his gunbelt, but his eyes are Cobb as he approaches, silhouetted against the flames.
You're still worried about the dog,  aren't you?
Paden ties his holster to his thigh.
You gotta calm down, Paden. Everything  will be put straight in a few days.
I saw how you're putting Mal Johnson  straight.

Something flicks through Cobb's eyes. He turns slowly and looks at the scene behind him. At the edge of the crowd a tired Stella sits on an overturned bucket, watching the f she wipes her sweaty brow with the sleeve of her dress. S looking that way --
I never could count on you to be  reasonable. (turns back to Paden) Don't force me to make an adjustment  around here.
Cobb, you've got nothing I need.
I'm not thinking about your future,  Paden. I'm worried about Stella.
What's she got to do with it?
Not a thing. She's just a mutual  friend. (a beat) But if you wind up on the wrong side  of this, she's going to get hurt.
Paden stares at Cobb, but now his eyes follow Cobb's righ hand, which swings up to Paden's shoulder.
I'm just trying to save you from  yourself. Don't change your luck.
Cobb lets his hand drop and begins to move away.
Get some sleep, Paden. Things'll  look better tomorrow.

Paden watches as Cobb walks over to Stella. Cobb takes a  handkerchief from his pocket and squats before Stella. He starts to wipe her forehead solicitously, but she takes t handkerchief from his hand. Cobb looks back at Paden as h rises and moves off. Paden turns and looks into the leaping flames. Our eyes c barely discern the change as these flames dissolve into  others, the fire now in --

The low fire illuminates Emmett, who is sitting on the ha He is sweating badly and seems to be concentrating on som rigorous task. Now we see what it is -- to stand up. He  struggles to his feet, wincing in pain, his hand steadyin against the rock. When he is upright, he tries to clear h head and finally lets go of the wall. For a moment he see all right. Then, suddenly, he drops heavily back to the f The fall sends more pain shooting through his ribs. He's  going nowhere.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF SILVERADO JAIL

text: Middle of the night. All is quiet, no one on the street. watches from the shadows across the street as DEPUTY FOX  leaves the jail and moves away. Rae goes toward the jail.
The place is nearly deserted. Paden sits alone at a table killing a bottle of the good stuff. Stella watches him po another drink.
Can't you drink any faster? We need  the bottles.
Paden throws her a look as she takes one of the empty cha
What is it that I can't figure?
What do you mean?
Cobb's got something on you, and it  must be pretty good.
Paden is impressed, even at this late date, by her acuity
What makes you say that?
If he didn't you'd never sit still  while this was happening.
You sure? Maybe that's the kind of  friend I am.

(laughs derisively) Nah! (moving on) What's he got? This is a nice saloon,  but there are other nice saloons.  It's not the money. Not for you. Why  can't I get ahold of it? (watches him take a  drink) Cobb says there's no telling what  you're going to care about.
(bitterly amused) Is that what he said? Well, he figured  it okay this time.

She regards him as he looks at his glass. Then he looks u and for one moment their eyes meet. Paden, uncomfortable, quickly looks away. In that second, she understands her o role in this. And she is deeply moved. They are silent  together.
Mal looks up as the door to the outer office clangs open. Deputy Garth comes in with Rae in tow. Mal comes to the f of his cell.
Look who's here, Johnson, it's your  sweet little sister. You remember  her, works at The Midnight Star.  Everybody knows her.
Mal and Rae look at each other.
She wanted to see you. Course I had  to search her. I'm not sure I did a  good job. Might have missed something. (holds up his bandaged  hand) Only got one good hand, you know.

Rae steps toward Mal, but Garth suddenly grabs her arm an flings her back against the wall opposite Mal's cell. He  moves close to Rae and slips the big ring of keys over hi bandaged right hand, freeing his left. He looks once at M then down Rae's body. His left hand fondles her.
Maybe I better check her a little  closer.

Mal's eyes flame as Garth takes Rae in a lascivious embra Suddenly Rae dips to one side within his arms. Her hand c up from her boot with Slick's dagger and plunges it into  Garth's back. The deputy jolts back a few steps in shock, already pulling a six-gun from his belt with his left han He fires once into Rae's body. She goes down. Garth is cocking the gun again with weakening fingers whe Mal's hand encircles his neck and pulls him violently bac against the bars. Garth's gun clatters away down the hall

location: STREET IN FRONT OF SILVERADO JAIL

text: Deputy Fox has heard the shot and is running toward the j

Garth, his neck broken, lies crumpled outside Mal's cell. Rae is unconscious and bloodied against the far wall. The large key ring is on the floor under Garth's leg and out Mal's reach. Mal's anguished gaze darts from Rae to the k as he begins to drag the dead weight of Garth's leg towar the bars. The key ring is dragged a few inches, then slip free. Mal tries again, then hears the front door SLAM ope in the outer office. Mal looks at the gun lying useless d the hall.
Fox draws his gun as he rushes across toward the cellbloc door.
Garth! You in there, Garth?

The keys still lie in the middle of the hall, the gun dow at the end. Fox comes through the door, gun raised, and takes in the  sight of the two bodies. He looks up in surprise as Slick dagger flies into his chest with a THUNK. Fox dies. Down the line of bars, Mal's right arm is extended into t corridor, as it was when he released the knife.

Paden is leaning all the way over the bar to extract a gl from beneath it. He straightens and walks back to the tab where Stella still sits. Now, however, she has drawn her  legs up before her on the chair and is hugging her knees, deep in thought. The saloon is now empty save for these t Paden pours them each a drink and hands Stella's to her.  This brings her back. He clinks his glass with hers and t
To my midnight star.
They exchange a long look, then drink.
Cobb's using me to stop you. So good  people are being hurt because of me. (a beat) That makes me mad.
Listening closely, he finds this last bit endearing.
Some people think because they're  stronger -- or meaner -- they can  push you around. I've seen a lot of  that. But it's only true if you let  it be. The world is what you make of  it.
I like your attitude. But it can be  risky.
I'm ready for that.
There is a challenge in her eyes as she reaches out and s the whiskey bottle away from him.
How about you?
I don't want you to get hurt.
He can't hurt me if he's dead.

Paden looks at her with growing appreciation. A light is  coming back into his face. A smile slowly grows on his li mirroring hers. The door behind the bar bangs open, and Phoebe comes out, breathless.
Stella, come quick!
Phoebe leads them into the dimly-lit room and goes to her knees beside Rae, who lies wounded on the floor. Rae is s conscious and moaning. Stella stoops to examine her wound
(crying) She sprung her brother... all by  herself! And this is what happened...  He brought her here.
Where'd he go?
I told him about Jake and the little  boy. He went off after Emmett.
(to Phoebe) Stop your crying. Go get Doc Skinner  and bring him to the shed. (to Paden) Pick her up.
Phoebe hurries out. Paden kneels next to Stella.
I've got a place I can hide her.
You better get in there with her  until this thing is over.

Emmett works by the light of the fire, checking one of th guns taken from the deputies. He hears something we do no but continues to work for a few moments more. Now we hear it: an approaching rider. Emmett stands up gingerly and m painfully back into the shadows. He is much improved but  still tentative. Mal comes into the cave carrying his Henry rifle. Emmett  reappears, lowering his gun.
I didn't think you were going to  make it back.
Mal steps into the light, revealing his bruised face.
I almost didn't.
(reacts to Mal's  condition) Where's Jake?
McKendrick's men got him.
Is he alive?
Mal indicates that he doesn't know. Emmett accepts that a picks up his gunbelt.
It's worse than that, Emmett.
Emmett looks up, waiting.
They took him at your sister's house.  Her husband was shot. I don't know  if he's going to make it.
Emmett feels real pain.
Kate?
She was hurt... pretty bad. (hates to tell him) Emmett, they took the little boy  with them.

Emmett lets this all sink in. And then his face and body  begin to transform. All the pain is swept away in a surgi current of vengeful energy. The MUSIC begins to build, as Emmett moves with eerie deliberateness to arm himself. He picks up one of the extra gunbelts and loops it over his  shoulder. Mal slides into his bandolier. Emmett indicates the gunbe remaining on the floor.
Want one of these?
Mal turns. He now holds his father's Henry rifle in addit to his own, one awesome weapon in each hand.
This oughta do.

Cobb, having just finished breakfast, steps out into the  morning light and looks around at his domain. He works th toothpick in his mouth and watches Tyree come slowly up t street on horseback. They nod their greetings and head do the street.
Tyree ties his horse in front, and the two men go inside.
Cobb is barely in the door when he stops, noticing someth out of place. The gun cabinet has been forced open; its  splintered door is ajar.
Garth! (nothing) Yo, Fox!
Tyree draws his gun, but Cobb is already moving toward th cellblock door.
Cobb and Tyree survey the scene: the empty cell, three po of blood, two bodies -- Garth and Fox. Cobb watches as Ty checks the two deputies and shakes his head.
Get Kyle and Dusty over here. And  keep your eyes open. I'm running out  of deputies.
He goes out.
The Bartender comes to the head of the stairs wearing a  nightshirt.
Stella ain't here, Sheriff. I checked  her room.
Now we see Cobb waiting at the bottom of the steps,  thoughtful.
And you don't know where Paden is?
Haven't seen him since last night.
Let me know if you do. And tell Stella  I want to see her.

Cobb turns and walks to the open, outer doors at the corn of the saloon. The swinging doors are still hooked back f the night. When Cobb stops in the doorway, he casts a lon shadow across the room. He stares out into the town for  several beats, then lifts his gun from its holster and ch the action.
The McKendrick brand is fashioned in wood at the peak of arch over the road. Beyond it, in the distance, cattle ar grazing on the rolling land.

Hundreds of cattle are grazing here in the morning light, sea of speckled hides. Now a Cowboy pulls up in the  foreground. He is heavily armed. His watchful gaze is not the cattle, but outward toward the horizon.
More Cowboys here, armed and watchful. Red comes along a  corral and climbs up onto a fence to peer into the distan

Scruffy, scratching his belly, walks along the porch of t main ranch house, the casa grande. As he comes up to us a the corner and looks around, we see that he is wearing Ja elaborately tooled, double gunbelt with the pearl-handled Colts. As he moves down the other side of the house, we see  McKendrick standing at a window, looking out.

We're behind McKendrick now. On the wall next to the wind there is a large, framed photograph of Murdo McKendrick, big, ferocious man, sitting rather stiffly in a chair. On one side of him stands his wife, as thin and tough as a n On the other, beneath a large, paternal hand, a small boy young Ethan. McKendrick turns away from the window and for an instant eye is stopped by the photograph. McKendrick looks unsett He hasn't slept.

Augie is huddled on a bed in the corner of the dark room, frightened, still wearing the nightshirt he had on when  abducted. Suddenly, sunlight blinds him. The Watching Cowboy from the night before has thrown open the curtains. He looks out over the roof of the veranda,  then turns back. He gives Augie an odd look and moves tow the door, first kicking a Guard Cowboy awake in his chair

Emmett and Mal ride side by side. Relentless. You wouldn' want to be the people they're going to visit. Now a solitary rider appears on the ridge above them, mov the same way. Mal notices him first, then Emmett. It is P and now he is sloping down to join them. He moves in alongside them. They exchange looks. Then all three look ahead. Where they are going.
Dr. Skinner has tended Rae on a cot in the dark recess of the shed and now moves with Stella to the door. Phoebe kn beside Rae.
If her skin gets cold, you better  come for me.
Stella nods, then cracks the door to peek outside.
WHAT SHE SEES. This shed is down the alley from the back the Midnight Star. The alley is empty.

Dr. Skinner comes out and begins to walk away. Slick appe from between two buildings. They nod to each other, and D Skinner walks away. Slick watches him for a moment, then  moves up the alley, looking around as he goes. He walks p the shed and on toward the street.
Slick reaches the end of the alley and stops. Cobb comes  down the sidewalk toward him. They talk confidentially. S shakes his head. They part, continuing their separate pro

IN THE CORRAL. One of the horses drinking at the trough l its head, ears twitching. A wave of restlessness goes thr the horses. On the top of the fence, Red notices and begi to listen intently. ON THE VERANDA. Scruffy stands up from a step and looks o toward the rise beyond the corrals. Alarm creeps into his face. AT THE BUNKHOUSE. Swann, his shoulder bandaged, comes out join a Sentry Cowboy looking with concern at the rise.  Suddenly, the Sentry Cowboy starts running toward a saddl horse nearby. Red has jumped from the fence now too and  mounted up quickly. The two horsemen head off toward the  rise at a gallop. Swann looks in alarm at -- THE CREST OF THE RISE. Pouring into view with a ground-sh RUMBLE is a huge herd of stampeding cattle. AT THE BUNKHOUSE. Swann turns to the door of the bunkhous and shouts inside.
Stampede!

ON THE RISE. Red and the Sentry Cowboy tear toward the  oncoming cattle. They fire their guns repeatedly in the a trying to turn the herd. AT THE CORRAL. Scruffy runs across from the casa grande a joins other Cowboys trying to saddle and mount panicked  horses. Scruffy's horse rears and breaks away from him. ON THE RISE. Red and the Sentry Cowboy are closing with t dust-enshrouded herd, still firing their guns. Suddenly,  from the cloud, there are answering shots. The Sentry Cow is shot dead off his horse. Emerging like a spirit from the dust at the edge of the h comes Emmett, six-gun in hand. On the other side of the herd, Paden's form materializes. aims his Winchester and fires. Red's horse rears. Red goe down and the herd pounds over him. AT THE BUNKHOUSE. Hoyt comes out the door, buckling on hi gunbelt. He looks at the on-rushing stampede, then toward the corral where several Cowboys are swinging up on their horses. Suddenly, there is gunfire from the roof of the  bunkhouse above Hoyt. One of the Cowboys in the corral go down. Another draws his gun and lifts it toward the bunkh but is shot before he can fire. The other Cowboys head fo cover. Hoyt stops some men who are coming out the door be him, and edges out to try to locate the source of the fir ON THE VERANDA. McKendrick comes out of the casa grande a runs to the corner of the veranda nearest the rise. He ta in the stampede, which is almost upon them now, then hear gunfire to his right. He looks back there and sees Mal on the bunkhouse roof, above Hoyt and firing from the protec of the raised rim. Now Mal swings his rifle around toward McKendrick. McKendrick jumps around the corner of the hou as the wall where he was standing takes a hit. SERIES OF SHOTS. The stampede hits the ranch. The herd sp the mass of cattle heading between the casa grande and th bunkhouse/corral area; the rest go around behind the casa grande. They take down everything in their way. Fences fa holding pens are destroyed, horses run free, and Cowboys  scramble away from the deadly current of rampaging cattle NEAR THE BARN. Paden pulls up on the edge of the flow and fires repeatedly at the Cowboys scrambling for safety. Sw is among those hit. BEHIND THE CASA GRANDE. Emmett pulls his horse out of the flow, protected by the building, then dismounts, ties the horse, and runs up to the back door of the house. He thro away the empty, extra six-gun in his hand as he looks  carefully inside. He draws his own gun and goes in. NEAR THE BARN. Paden is coming under increasing fire from the bunkhouse as the cattle thin. He rides into the barn the end of the corral. AT THE BUNKHOUSE. Hoyt directs some of his men, including Scruffy, to work their way along under the eaves of the  bunkhouse and go after Paden. Hoyt glances upward toward sound of Mal's rifle.

Emmett works his way carefully down the central hall, gun ready. He looks up the main staircase, sees nothing, and  edges forward. At the top of the stairs behind him, the  Watching Cowboy jumps into view. Emmett spins and ducks a the Watching Cowboy fires. The finial splinters. Emmett's shot follows immediately. The Watching Cowboy is hit and  tumbles the full length of the stairs, dead.

ON THE VERANDA. McKendrick reacts to the shots behind him his house. He moves toward a window and opens it. ON THE BUNKHOUSE ROOF. Mal switches to his father's Henry and shifts around to fire at some outriding Cowboys who a thundering in from the range. AT THE BARN. Three cowboys dive through the main door in  pursuit of Paden. Scruffy, one of Jake's pearl-handled Co at the ready, sneaks along the side of the barn.

Emmett moves away from the stairwell and cautiously round corner, focused on an open bedroom door up ahead. Suddenl the Guard Cowboy steps boldly into view in that doorway, raised, using Augie as a shield. Emmett cannot fire. He d back around the corner as the Guard Cowboy gets off a sho Seeing his miss, the Guard Cowboy slams closed the bedroo door and locks it. Instantly Emmett is running that way. He flies into the  bedroom next door.

The Guard Cowboy has backed against the wall, gun raised  toward the door. Augie is still clutched to his chest. The window overlooking the roof of the veranda implodes a Emmett arrives in a shower of glass. The stunned Guard Co spins, opening an angle between himself and Augie. Emmett doesn't need much. He fires before he stops rolling. The  Guard Cowboy falls back against the wall.

McKendrick, gun poised, stands over the body of the Watch Cowboy, reacting to the shots above. He is about to go up there when the front door crashes open as a Cowboy, shot Mal, staggers into the hall. He leans against the hall ta and fires out the door. Two more shots from Mal finish th Cowboy and a large vase. McKendrick changes him mind about going upstairs. He move quickly toward the door at the back of the house.
Augie is trembling in Emmett's arms. Emmett soothes him,  then looks into his tear-stained face.
Augie, where's Jake?
(chokes it out) He's dead.
Emmett reacts to this hard news.
They hung him!
Slowly a peculiar twinkle grows in Emmett's eyes.
They hung him?

AT THE BUNKHOUSE. Hoyt is hugging the side wall of the  bunkhouse. He warily looks around the back corner. WHAT HE SEES. Mal's horse is tethered near a stack of cra and barrels that rises almost to the roof.

Paden is in an empty stall part-way down one side of the  barn. The three Cowboys have him pinned down from the fro Paden's horse does a panicky dance in the central aisle. horses in the other stalls are spooked. Scruffy sneaks in the back door of the barn. He peeks aro the wall of a stall at Paden's unprotected back. When he  sees Paden stop to reload his Colt, Scruffy steps out and aims at him. Quite unexpectedly, someone swings down from the loft abo kicking Scruffy and sending him flying into the recess of stall. Now the figure drops into view. It's Jake! He dive after Scruffy. Paden, reloaded now and unaware of the struggle behind hi has to shrink back from a splintering rail. Now he hears muffled shots from the back of the barn. He looks over th After a beat, Jake steps into Paden's view, grinning like maniac and happily buckling his reacquired gunbelt. Paden does a double take. Jake gives him a big "Here I am!" ges then indicates he's going up to the loft again to help ou with the guys up front. But first, with real relish, he c his pearl-handled Colts: he draws both at once, tips them to look into the cylinders, then spins them back into the holsters. Then, with a leap, to the loft.
McKendrick rides flat out toward town.

There are Cowboys in the first stalls on each side of the barn, and a third in a stall closer to Paden. Jake drops  down from the loft behind the first two, his guns in his  holsters. They both see him and react. Jake draws both gu and shoots one, spins, and shoots the other. The third Cowboy turns to look. His mistake. Paden flies  into view and shoots him dead. Paden approaches Jake with wonder. Jake shows him an ugly bruise where the rope was around his neck. When he speaks it is in a hoarse whisper --
New record.
(slaps him on the  back) Let's get out of here.
Paden catches his horse and swings up. Jake pulls a horse from a stall. It is the much-contested pinto, bare-backed but bridled. Paden rides out the back of the barn.

BACK OF THE BARN. Paden rides out, but pulls up when he  notices that Jake is not following. He is about to go bac when something catches his eye. WHAT HE SEES. Hoyt is just climbing onto the roof of the  bunkhouse, catty-corner from Mal's position. Paden squeezes off a shot, but Hoyt has already disappear from view. Paden looks along the bunkhouse, where he can Mal firing. Mal is protected at present from Hoyt by the chimney he is braced against. But if he isn't warned, Hoy will surprise him. A Cowboy in the bunkhouse spots Paden fires at him. Paden must warn Mal quickly. Yelling is hop in the din. Paden aims carefully at Mal and fires. AT MAL. The chimney is hit just above Mal's head. He swin his rifle around toward -- Paden! Paden signals wildly ab Hoyt. Mal understands just in time: he flops around the  chimney just as Hoyt gets a bead on him. Without knowing Mal avenges his father's murder. Hoyt is blown off the ro The bulk of the herd has passed, but confused cattle are  everywhere. AT THE VERANDA. Jake has ridden across the open area unde heavy fire and now rides for protection up and onto the s veranda of the house, firing into all the windows. His  momentum carries him all the way out the other end. When is beyond the porch, he hears a yell, two voices --
Jake!?!

Jake looks up with a grin. Emmett has Augie out on the ro of the veranda. They are pleased in the extreme at the si of Jake. Jake brings his horse beneath them and gestures Augie. Augie swallows hard once, strides twice, and leaps out, d and onto the bare back of the pinto behind Jake. Paden comes riding up with Emmett's horse in tow. Emmett  moves to the edge of the veranda roof and drops into his  saddle. He winces, his ribs throbbing. They turn their ho away from the ranch and head out.

The three horses with four riders come tearing toward us. They form a dusty "V" as they intersect with Mal's arriva from the other side of the bunkhouse. Even now, shots are fired after them. But they are on their way.

The SHOPKEEPER is placing items in his front window when eye is caught by something across the street. We can see  only a dim reflection of it in the glass. With a concerne look, the Shopkeeper comes outside. WHAT HE SEES. Trouble. Five men, loaded for bear, are com out of Cobb's office: Cobb, McKendrick, Tyree, Kyle, and  DUSTY, another deputy.
Dusty mounts up and rides toward the center of town. Kyle goes off in another direction on foot. McKendrick unhitch his horse and speaks to Cobb with some bitterness.
It never should've got this far,  Cobb.
Cobb eyes him coolly.
This is as far as it's going.
McKendrick swings up and jacks a cartridge into the chamb of his Winchester. He's not as confident as Cobb.
I'll do my part. But you better watch  your ass. These guys'll shoot it  off.
He heads off in the same direction as Dusty. Tyree moves next to Cobb.
I'm gonna enjoy this.
Cobb gives him a sideways glance, then looks around wistf
This used to be a peaceful town.
Tyree moves off in yet a new direction. The Shopkeeper  approaches Cobb nervously.
What's going on, Sheriff?
Hide and watch.
The Shopkeeper reacts big and scurries away to spread the word.

Dusty pulls up at the hotel on the corner and throws his  reins over the post. Then, with rifle in hand, he stands his saddle and climbs to the roof of the porch. He looks  down the street, cocks his rifle, and settles into hiding behind the hotel sign. McKendrick rides by slowly, exchanging looks with Dusty, moves down the street. Several townspeople have seen Dusty. The panicky, street- clearing word spreads.
Rae writhes in pain on the cot. Stella's hand is on Rae's forehead as she speaks to Phoebe.
Better bring the doc. (as Phoebe turns) Be careful.
The Milliner is urgently closing the shutters on his shop passersby hurry for home. Phoebe edges out of the alley  nearby, turns, and finds herself face to face with Tyree. regards her malevolently.
Where you going?
(scared) Nowhere.
This is no time to be on the streets.  Maybe you oughta come along with me.
He grasps her arm hard and pulls her along the sidewalk.
The four horsemen and the boy pull up near the cemetery a look down at Silverado. Jake lowers Augie to the ground.  Emmett hands him a blanket and speaks down to him.
Stay here till we get back. Don't  come in.
The four riders look from the town to each other and chec their weapons.
(to them all) I'll see you around.
(smiles) Last one to the Midnight Star buys.
You're on! Let's get 'em!
Jake kicks the bare-back into motion and tears off direct toward town. Emmett heads off to the left. Paden begins t move after Jake, but slower. Mal stops him with --
Hey, Paden...
They look at each other.
Good luck.
Paden nods it back to him, and the bond is re-formed. Mal heads off at a gallop to the right. They are all going to enter town from different directions.

Rae MOANS loudly, and Stella instinctively reaches out to quiet her, worried about discovery. Stella throws a frust glance toward the door -- where is Phoebe? She can't wait. She goes to the door and peeks out.

Slick checks Rae's room and closes the door. He too is  frustrated. Now he looks out the hall window, down at the alley. WHAT HE SEES. Stella steps quickly out of the storage she and moves away. Slick runs for the steps.

Slick runs past the shed door and peers between buildings search of Stella. She's gone. He comes back to the shed.  Before opening the door he does an odd thing: he chops hi left forearm sharply downward and a shiny derringer slide crisply into his grip from beneath his sleeve. He enters  cautiously.
Slick moves through the dim light. He hears a MOAN and st forward. He looks down at Rae. Half-delirious, she focuse on him and reacts in terror. He makes the derringer disap and kneels beside her.
Don't be afraid, baby. I'll stay  with you until your little friend  comes back.
Jake comes riding down the street, waving his hat, WHOOPI and HOLLERING. The few remaining pedestrians run for cove at the sight.
(yelling) Come on out, boys! Jake's in town!  Let's start the ball!

Jake jumps off the pinto and hitches it in front of the  saloon. As he approaches the entrance, set in the cut-off corner of the building, he executes a fast pirouette, sca down all four blocks that meet here. He finds the doors l and kicks them open with a loud BANG. He goes inside.
Tyree has heard the commotion and moves toward it.
Stella is pounding on the door without luck. She gives up looks around, and hurries off.

Tyree stops across the street from the Midnight Star and  looks at Jake's horse and the open doors. Across the  intersection Kyle appears at a run. Tyree motions him to around the back of the saloon. Tyree runs across the stre When he is on the porch of the saloon, he pulls his gun a begins edging toward the open doors.

It's dark in here with the shutters closed. Tyree jumps  inside, gun poised. When Kyle bangs through from the back Tyree almost shoots him. They scan the room and advance  cautiously into the shadows. Nobody here. Now they back o eyeing the dark stairwell. When they are safely on the porch, Tyree motions for Kyle go down one side of the building while he starts down the other. Jake appears from beneath Stella's ramp behind the bar an vaults lightly over the bar. In a moment he stands just i the open doorway. He peeks out, then turns so his back is the outside, his guns still holstered.
Jake backs quietly out onto the porch. When he stops, he see both Tyree and Kyle moving along their respective por
Hey!
Tyree and Kyle spin at the sound. Only then does Jake dra both guns and, pointing them in two completely different  directions, he shoots both men at once.

Slick has made himself comfortable next to Rae, who has f into a fitful sleep. Now he hears something. The door of shed opens and closes. He waits confidently for Stella to appear around the intervening wall of barrels and crates. But he's looking too low. Mal steps into view, the big He rifle in his hand. Slick's eyes widen, but he gets contro quickly and rises, trying to gauge Mal's attitude. Mal looks from Rae to Slick and back to Rae.
I'm glad you're here, Mal. I've been  watching her, but she needs a doctor.
Yeah.

He looks at Slick as he leans his rifle against the wall. Slick looks at the rifle, then at Mal. Mal seems to  concentrate on Rae and makes a move that way. When he is  past Slick, Slick makes the peculiar, chopping gesture of his left forearm that snaps the derringer into his hand. Mal has been waiting for something and is already turning into Slick. Before Slick can raise his gun hand, Mal has  Slick's wrist in a vise-like grip. Mal's other arm encirc Slick's torso and crushes him against Mal's body. Two str men strain against each other. The cocked derringer wavers perilously toward the sleepin Rae. Suddenly, Mal twists Slick around, banging his hand  into the wall, and the derringer fires. Slick lets it cla to the floor. Rae wakes with a start and watches the combatants in terr The men's eyes are only inches apart. Something flashes  through Mal's and he loosens his embrace. Instantly, Slic dips to the right, lifting his boot to his hand. But his  dagger is not there. Slick's surprised look is answered by Mal's tight grin.
Looking for this?
Their bodies jerk as Slick gets his last surprise and goe limp in Mal's arms. He falls to the floor, his own boot d protruding from his ribcage. Mal kneels to embrace his sister.
